—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. I refer the minister to the August balance of payments figures, which revealed a deficit of $2.1 billion for that month, the third highest on record, and the continued trend decline in Australia's balance of payments situation. As the trade deficit has recorded monthly deficits of $1.4 billion, $1.7 billion, $1.8 billion, $1.6 billion, $1.8 billion and now this $2.1 billion over the last six months, what policy changes will the government be implementing to address this looming crisis, or is Australia going to continue to go through the boom-bust cycle of Labor's economic policy?

—While the debt service ratio remains as low as it is, it is absolutely nonsensical to talk in terms of the balance of payments situation as constituting any kind of serious problem for the Australian economy. The rise in the current account deficit in August was, of course, mainly due to a rise in investment related imports. Too much weight should not be placed on any month's figures, and that is particularly true of August and its outcome because of not only the very high general level of monthly volatility that applies in these estimates but, for example, the particular impact that was made in the August figures by the two Qantas aircraft, valued at $248 million alone, which happened to be part and parcel of those figures.

PARA.TAB: The outlook for the current account deficit is not simply a matter, as we all should know by now—although we go through this idiotic process almost every month with the opposition seeking to score points—of extrapolating a few months' estimates, as some media commentators and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate have done. The truth of the matter is that some deterioration in the current account deficit was always to be expected at this stage of the cycle, given the underlying strength of the Australian economy.

Investment is now unquestionably and unequivocally growing strongly, with underlying plant and equipment investment, for example, rising 15.6 per cent over the year to June. This is, of course, increasing imports of capital equipment. Those imports will, as again we have said on innumerable occasions, increase Australia's productive capacity, increase our future income, and increase in particular our capacity to make further export income and, as such, have a positive impact in the longer term on the balance of payments itself.

Manufactured exports continue to respond very well indeed to the improved economic environment. Our international competitiveness has improved by around 30 per cent over the last 10 years. It is being further helped by continuing low inflation and wage rises and by strong productivity growth. We had exports of ETMs—elaborately transformed manufactures—growing by 16 per cent in the last financial year, 1993-94.

So the runs are on the board. Everyone knows that the Australian economy is growing as well as that of any other developed economy in the world; in fact, substantially better than the overwhelming majority of them. All the basic elements are there for a continuation of that strong growth. That strong growth is unquestionably taking the form of a surge in investment related imports at the moment. That in turn will feed back into the productive capacity of the economy and our ability to make more returns from exports in the future. It is exactly where we would expect to be at this stage of the economic cycle. Those opposite should stop whingeing about it and get on with the job for once and be a little bit more helpful and productive in their own approach to the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The problem is that we are hearing exactly the same from this government as we heard in the lead-up to the worst recession in 60 years: that is, the minister in the late 1980s came in here and said, `Don't worry about it because the debt service ratio is okay and, in any event, it is only an importation of capital goods.' My supplementary question therefore is: if we are having the same scenario that is going to lead to the same disastrous result as last time, with one million Australians out of work and the worst recession in 60 years, why will this government not tackle it in a different way from last time? Last time the government's solution was to push up interest rates, which is what is occurring again in this instance, with the disastrous consequences that I mentioned. That is why we are asking the minister why he does not find a different way to approach the cycle this time, instead of seeing Australia go through another boom and bust with the same tragic results as last time.

—The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate does not know or does not want to know the basic realities about the underlying strengths of this economy following the entire process that we went through during the 1980s. We have a much stronger position right now than we had at any stage during the 1980s—in particular, in those years just before the last recession. We have strength in the underlying growth rate, now running at around 4 1/2 per cent. We have strength in the underlying inflation rate, down to around two to 2 1/2 per cent. We have strength in the basic productivity gains that are being made and consolidated. We have strength in the continuing industrial relations environment and the productivity that continues to be delivered by that. We have strength in the low interest rate regime which is applicable at the moment and which will be maintained, notwithstanding adjustments that are obviously going to be necessary from time to time, as is always the case when we get into an economic cycle of this particular kind in the recovery phase.

PARA.TAB: We have exports that are unquestionably growing more strongly in the manufactured sector and in the elaborately transformed manufactures sector than at any previous time in our history. There is no basis whatsoever for this type of doom and gloom saying by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. Following reports of massive numbers of Iraqi troops near Iraq's border with Kuwait, I ask: can the minister inform the Senate of the Australian government's position in light of these recent reports? Further, what is the current situation involving any Australians in Kuwait or Iraq? Has Australia been approached to provide any military support to allied deployments in the gulf?

—The latest information available to me is that seven divisions of Iraqi troops have moved to within 25 to 30 kilometres of the border with Kuwait. Iraqi troops do not at this stage appear to be operationally ready for an invasion of Kuwait; however, their proximity to the border and the presence of major elements of three divisions of Iraq's elite Republican Guard do, of course, give rise for some concern in that respect. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's intentions are unclear. They certainly have not been made public. He has not indicated the purpose of these troop movements and he has not given a reliable assurance that Iraq harbours no aggressive intention towards Kuwait.

PARA.TAB: In response to these developments it is, of course, the case that Kuwait has initiated defensive deployments of its own and it has called on military support from the United States and the United Kingdom, which has been provided to the extent that the US has deployed 4,000 troops to Kuwait, placed another 14,000 on special alert and is moving an aircraft carrier into the region. The UK is also in the process of deploying naval assets to the gulf.

It has been, I suppose, the general assessment—it is shared by our own officials who are tracking and monitoring these events very closely—that it is unlikely that there will be an aggressive act against Kuwait in the near future; but, of course, nobody is making any absolute assumptions about that and the readiness to deal with a situation of this kind, should it arise, is as I have described it. The view that has been taken is that, given the lack of operational readiness that presently exists among the Iraqi troops, the time taken to gain operational readiness would be ample for necessary counterforce deployments to be put in place.

While no-one is entirely clear about what the Iraqi motives are in this whole affair, clearly their behaviour does seem linked to the question of the continued application of sanctions and, in this context, any further Iraqi moves seem likely to follow or be delayed until the release in New York today—New York time—of the report of the head of the UN Special Commission, which has the responsibility of ensuring the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. Iraq has demanded that that report set a time frame for monitoring the elimination of these weapons, after which the council would consider the lifting of sanctions against Iraq. We will need to await, I guess, the course of events over the next 24 hours in relation to the content of that report and Iraq's reaction to it.

As to the Australian position, we certainly fully support the statement by the President of the Security Council two days ago emphasising the necessity for Iraq to fully implement all relevant Security Council resolutions and reaffirming the Security Council's commitment to Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Apart from two Australian Defence Force personnel serving with the UN Special Commission in Baghdad, Australia has no military personnel or units presently in the gulf. There has been no approach to the Australian government to contribute to the current defensive build-up in Kuwait.

Our embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, has been in contact with the Australian community in Kuwait, which reports that the situation in Kuwait City remains quite calm. Arrangements are in place for liaison and rapid communication of advice on the situation within the Australian community. We will continue to closely monitor the situation and will remain in close contact in particular with the Australian community in Kuwait through our embassy in Riyadh and also with the Australian community in Iraq, including Care Australia representatives in northern Iraq, through our embassy, in this case, in Amman.

—Could the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the Senate of progress made in implementing the drought relief package that the Prime Minister announced on 21 September?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that as from today farmers in exceptional drought areas can apply for the new drought relief payment. The package announced on 21 September is part of an ongoing process.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

I am sorry, Senator Boswell: the opposition seems to have lost interest in the drought. The package announced on 21 September is part of an ongoing process. Commonwealth government expenditure either made or committed to this drought is now in excess of a quarter of a billion dollars. I will take a further submission to cabinet addressing long-term issues such as taxation incentives to encourage farmers to better plan for drought.

The drought package is targeted at farmers in extreme drought. This is consistent with the national drought policy that was agreed between the Commonwealth and states in 1992, which recognised extreme drought as that which good managers could not be expected to factor into their risk planning. The current package is aimed at those farmers in exceptional circumstances areas. Areas in which support is not available will attract assistance as they meet the exceptional circumstances test.

Applications for the drought relief payment commenced today, with back payment to 1 October. Payment will be equivalent to the jobsearch allowance but, unlike other income support payments, only non-farm assets will be taken into account in the assets test. Recipients of the drought relief payment will automatically qualify for the health care card, and their farm assets are excluded from the assets test for Austudy. For a family with three children, one of whom is attending a tertiary institution, the package is worth around $25,000 a year.

My colleague Minister Beddall will introduce legislation to the house this week to implement the drought relief payment, and I look forward to receiving the support of the Senate in its speedy passage. The introduction of the drought relief payment is accompanied by increased funding and changing of the administration of the exceptional circumstances provisions of RAS. The package announced on 21 September changed the funding of RAS exceptional circumstances provisions to a demand-driven program. In addition, the total amount of RAS support available to an individual farm enterprise has been increased from a maximum annual limit of $50,000 to $100,000, while the cumulative limit over five years has been lifted from $100,000 to $300,000. The off-farm assets test has been eased to protect farmers' insurance and superannuation investments.

On a related issue, there is much concern about the availability of grain in Australia as a result of this drought. I asked ABARE about a fortnight ago to undertake a national grain audit to give the government a clearer picture of this situation. I expect to have that information shortly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. At the recent ALP conference the minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the best way in which we can be influential over the East Timor issue is by acting within the framework of an effective multi-dimensional relationship with Indonesia and to encourage them by every available means to do the right thing.

At the same time the Secretary-General of Amnesty International, Mr Pierre Sane, said that there is no evidence that the minister's quiet diplomacy approach to human rights has worked in East Timor, and he cites the unchecked torture, political killings and unfair trials. So I ask the question Mr Sane asks. Is Australia's current human rights policy on Indonesia built on sand? What are these means of encouragement available to the minister? What has this approach delivered to the East Timorese?

TALK.START.PARA: —The term `quiet diplomacy' is not one that I readily embrace. It is far more often used by others to describe our approach than by me. I would describe our approach as not so much quiet diplomacy but productive diplomacy. That means, in turn, principled diplomacy, being prepared to raise these issues in every environment around the world where it is appropriate to do so, where issues of this kind arise, and to do so by reference not to western standards but to universal standards of decency, human liberty and dignity.

PARA.TAB: I would describe our approach as a pragmatic one in this context because what we do want to do is ensure that we do generate results and do not just generate self-indulgent self-glorification, which is the character that unfortunately a great deal of posturing on these subjects has in a number of countries around the world. What we want to do is do that which is appropriate to get responses, and on occasions that might require not quiet diplomacy or anything like it but a great deal of noise, a great deal of public expressions of distaste and, in fact, sanctions measures to go with it. We have been party to that kind of activity on many occasions around the world and over the years when we have deemed that to be likely to be productive because of the nature of the international constituency or whatever that we have been able to harness for that cause.

Our diplomacy is also, I guess, characterised in a number of these instances by a quality of patience because we do believe that there are many kinds of human rights achievements and advances which are likely to be realised only in a context of changing economic circumstances or things of this kind which will create those kinds of pressures. It is not a matter of waiting for that to occur and not taking any other steps; it is a matter of recognising that that is another element which is sometimes part of the equation.

In the particular context of East Timor and the Amnesty report that Senator Kernot has quoted, our concern is that that report is not anything other than a campaign document. It is not an objective or a measured or balanced analysis of the situation either in Indonesia overall or in East Timor in particular. It is the case that the trends in human rights performance in Indonesia are not measured in that report in any kind of balanced or carefully assessed way. While it is the case that Indonesian performance still falls well short of international human rights standards in many respects—and the report quite correctly points that out—it does fail to note that by historical standards there have indeed been significant improvements; and that has to be taken into account in making any assessment of where Indonesia has come from and where it is going.

It is also the case that that report wholly obscures the improvements which unquestionably have taken place in economic and social rights, whatever may be the case or whatever Senator Kernot's assessment may have been when focused solely on civil and political rights. It is important that that be taken into account in any fair assessment of the situation in East Timor, just as elsewhere in Indonesia. The report is also weak, I think, and unhelpful to the extent that it does not make any constructive suggestions at all about processes which might actually improve the human rights situation, particularly at this crucial period of transition in Indonesian society.

The situation in East Timor is not as good as we would like it to be, but there is no element of complacency that I can discern among the governing and other elites in Indonesia about that state of affairs. The whole question about the best way to move forward a reconciliation process in East Timor is the subject of very lively and intense and very current discussion in Jakarta right now. I had an opportunity last week in the United Nations in New York to contribute something further to that discussion, and I believe that now, as indeed more generally, the best way Australia can move the situation forward in East Timor, which unquestionably needs to be done, is through making suggestions and being persistently encouraging and persistently quite carefully descriptive in our representations to the Indonesian government against the background of a multidimensional relationship with Indonesia, which will ensure that our voice will be heard and will be taken seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister able to provide the Senate with a report on developments with respect to the peace process on Bougainville Island? In spite of some difficulties, is it accurate to say that the peace conference will commence today? What are the prospects for an enduring peace being found on Bougainville? How is the Australian government assisting in underpinning the processes that are involved?

—The peace process in Bougainville so far as the conference is concerned is only in its very early stages. The conference was scheduled to start today, as Senator Loosley has said. Reports most recently available to me indicate that it has commenced on schedule, but we have not as yet had a complete readout on the extent of the participation in it, the particular individuals and those others in attendance and their representative status.

PARA.TAB: The BRA commander, Sam Kauona, is understood to have travelled to Bougainville last night, notwithstanding some recent indications that he was not going to attend the conference; and that obviously is a good sign. The Bougainville cease-fire committee, which does include BRA representation, has been working actively to maintain conditions for the conference to proceed. I should say in that respect that we are, of course, aware of reports that several individuals, including members of the PNGDF, were wounded by gunfire yesterday, but that was an isolated instance for which the BRA has denied responsibility and it is our assessment that that will not disrupt the peace process.

We have a situation where a wide cross-section of Bougainvillians and representatives from the PNG government are expected to be at this conference, including representatives from church groups, unions, women's groups and the interim authorities covering the various regions of the island. We also welcome the presence of UN observers and administrative support for the conference.

The South Pacific peacekeeping force, which was formed to facilitate these talks, is now fully deployed with an advance party having arrived in Arawa two days ago to prepare for the arrival of the main contingent yesterday. There are about 400 personnel involved in the operation, with Fiji supplying some 230, Tonga 110 and Vanuatu 50. Australia is providing HMAS Tobruk which, anchored as it is in Arawa Bay, will be the combined force headquarters, and HMAS Success which will provide supply support. We are also making available Black Hawk helicopters and Caribou aircraft to assist in transport and logistic requirements and up to 50 personnel, as required, to undertake logistic communications, medical and movement support for the contingent actually on the ground.

The presence of this peacekeeping force was provided for under the Honiara commitments to peace on Bougainville, which were signed, as honourable senators will recall, by PNG Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan and BRA Commander Kauona, on 3 September. The force is operating under a multilateral status of forces agreement signed by the governments concerned. It is intended to play a wholly neutral role and in fact will play quite a limited role in support of the peace process. It is essentially a role of providing security for the participants at the peace conference now under way. It will also have a role monitoring the situation in declared neutral zones at Panguna, Buin and Wakunai. We have been happy to provide support, as requested, to that force. At the same time, I repeat what I have said previously publicly: we have underlined to the PNG government and others directly involved that they alone are responsible for the conduct and outcome of the peace conference.

It is intended that the conference will conclude on 16 October with a peace ceremony. There is no proposal for a continuing or open-ended peacekeeping presence on Bougainville. If that peace ceremony does go ahead, as is hoped, on the weekend of 16 October, a number of representatives will be there from neighbouring countries including, I hope, me, representing Australia, and hopefully also the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth, Emeka Anyaoku, to demonstrate our witnessing, as it were, of what we are all hoping will be a very successful process.

It is obviously too early to make a judgment about how successful this process will be but certainly it remains, as I have said before, far and away the most helpful development that we have seen in the resolution of this distressing ongoing conflict in Bougainville. Once again, I think the committee headed by Senator Loosley is to be thanked for the work that it did in creating the environment for this process to proceed and, in particular, for the concept of this conference to take hold as it has. We can all only hope that there will be a successful outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister can only acknowledge that Cambodia is a mess that poses acute problems for Australian foreign policy. I ask: why in his continually optimistic speeches this year about Cambodia has the minister covered up the facts about the grossly corrupt government which has developed there? Why has the minister not responded to General Sanderson's warnings? In particular, why has the minister not publicly responded to former Ambassador Holloway's final, highly critical summary account of last June? And what is his response to the Holloway assessment now? Finally, I ask: why has the minister denied this parliament an informed and frank account of developments in Cambodia?

—There are two reasons why I have not responded in detail to that leaked document: firstly, because, in accordance with established government practice, it is not appropriate to comment on leaked documents; and secondly, because in the present circumstances when we are all trying very hard to resolve a very delicate and difficult situation with the hostages, I do not think it would be helpful to do so. However, given the fact that Senator Teague has repeated once again the canard which has constantly been echoed, I have noticed, in newspaper reports and editorial comment over the last few days about my alleged statements on this subject, let me get once and for all the chronology straight.

PARA.TAB: It is not the case that the contents of this cable are inconsistent with the assessments that I have been giving publicly about the situation in Cambodia. The last time I did express some very real confidence that things were generally going very well in Cambodia was on the occasion of my last actual visit there in April this year—8 and 9 April. But it was only a couple of weeks after that, on 19 April, that the debacle occurred in which the Khmer Rouge recaptured Pailin from Cambodian government troops with a lot of consequential adverse morale effects flowing from that to the government itself, with a degree of fragility and vulnerability creeping into the administration of the country in a whole variety of ways as a result.

Since that happened I have been very careful indeed in all of my public statements about the situation in Cambodia and have often pointed to the fragility and vulnerability of the situation and the need for those of us around the world genuinely committed to the country to be prepared to be as helpful as we can and as responsive as we can to this new, very difficult phase in the evolution of the country.

I make the further point, however, that the cable in question is dated June; it is now October. The sky has not fallen in during the intervening period. I am not entirely clear what Senator Teague or anyone else is getting so excited about. I have never made any secret of the fact that a country such as Cambodia, emerging as it is from decades of civil war and the most horrific abuses of human rights, can hardly be expected to turn into a fully functioning democracy overnight. I have also made no secret of the fact that Australia—and I myself—has constantly made vigorous representations to the highest levels of the Cambodian government and its armed forces about individual cases of abuse, about the need for a widening and deepening of democratic structures and about a general need for reform in a number of governing institutions, not least the military.

Despite some inevitable hitches along the way, our assessment, and that of others, including people such as Justice Michael Kirby, the UN Special Representative on Human Rights, is that progress is being made on most of these fronts. We, of course, are continuing to play our part in the international effort to reconstruct Cambodia, including in the propagation and consolidation of democratic norms, by providing assistance to the Cambodian government and to non-governmental bodies aimed, among other things, at building and strengthening democratic institutions and the rule of law.

I continue to believe very strongly, as Mr Holloway does—and let it not be forgotten that this is a central part of the assessment of Mr Holloway, if this document is to be regarded as an accurate representation of his views—that the democratically elected government of Cambodia remains that country's best hope for the future. It is also the case that, as his health permits, King Sihanouk will continue to play a very important role, as will other institutions and people in prominent places in that country.

I have no intention—this government has no intention whatsoever—of walking away from the responsibility that the international community has taken for Cambodia. I believe that just about everyone else around the world who has taken a responsible interest in this would take a similar view. The key to the country's future prosperity is economic growth and development. That requires security. The alternative—a resurgence of the Khmer Rouge—is simply too horrible to contemplate. Details of how we might best respond to the situation in which the country finds itself are still being worked out by a number of countries with which we have been discussing these things. They will be considered by the Australian government in due course. I do not intend to pre-empt any further decision we might make in this respect by any further comment at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Why does the minister persist in personal defences of assessments he made up to April and has continued to make since? Why is he painting Cambodia and the outcome there with a white brush when his officers are painting it with a black brush? In his reference to the `purported' cable from former Ambassador Holloway, is he saying that the document that he cabled as ambassador is not his cable, does not represent his words, is not his assessment? Finally, I ask the minister to table in the Senate by question time tomorrow all of his written responses and other notes arising from then Ambassador Holloway's final cables before he left his post last June.

—Senator Teague can ask all he likes but he is not getting anything of the kind, and he should not expect to. As to whatever else I might have said about purported cables, it is not a matter of casting any doubt other than to say this: when it comes to leaked documents I am not in the business of confirming their status or their content. It is not helpful to any system of government when one is trying to deal with difficult and delicate matters of this kind.

PARA.TAB: As to the other part of the supplementary question, Senator Teague simply was not listening to what I said. If he goes back carefully and looks at the chronology of what I have said on the public record in this place and elsewhere, he will see there has been no inconsistency whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the UN you defended the government of Cambodia.

—I am defending the continued responsibility of the international community and Australia to do what we constructively can to make that country work. If Senator Teague wants us to walk away from it, if he wants the international community to walk away from it and allow the conditions to be recreated for the resurgence of the Khmer Rouge, then he will have that very badly indeed on his conscience. That is not my position; that is not the government's position; and it is not the international community's position.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer him to the peace talks between Bougainville and Papua New Guinea that began today, and the news that the Bougainville Revolutionary Army commander Sam Kauona has threatened to pull out of the peace talks because both Australia and Papua New Guinea have jointly broken the cease-fire agreement. I ask, first, whether the minister believes that the Australian government has broken the cease-fire agreement by appointing Australians to the peacekeeping force, despite the fact that the force was meant to be totally neutral under the terms of the agreement and the Bougainville negotiators believe Australia is central to the conflict. Secondly, does the minister agree that the aspect of the cease-fire agreement referring to the border having to be monitored by a neutral third party has been broken following the departure of 650 Australian troops on HMAS Tobruk and HMAS Success to the area, without the consent of the BRA or the Bougainville interim government? Thirdly, will the Australian government accept any responsibility for the breakdown in the peace talks if the BRA and BIG pull out of the peace talks because of Australian interference in the cease-fire agreement?

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Time!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Gratuitous advice to the chair is most unhelpful. I can read a clock as well as members of the government and the opposition.

—There are a few contenders for the honour of being Senator Margetts's most muddled question in this place, but I have to say that that one is getting pretty close, in terms of the suggestions in it that Australia's participation and logistic role in the peacekeeping force somehow involves a breach or a potential breach of the cease-fire agreement entered into by Sir Julius Chan and Sam Kauona. It cannot conceivably be characterised in that role. The Australian force is not playing any role other than that of logistic support in order to get on the ground the 230 personnel from Fiji, the 110 personnel from Tonga and the 50 personnel from Vanuatu who constitute the peacekeeping forces. It is only Australia in the region that had the logistic capacity to move those sorts of numbers quickly to get them in there in accordance with the timetable that Sir Julius Chan had agreed with his BRA interlocutor.

PARA.TAB: We have been playing what I think has been universally perceived as a helpful role in this respect. It is not an active role on the ground in any way other than that I have described. We retain some overall coordinating responsibility for it because of our logistic role and the necessity to coordinate all the elements coming together in this way, but the command of the force on the ground is with the Tongan and Fijian commanding officers, not with the Australians. That remains the case. The Australian role in this respect was well understood, I think, in prospect at the time of the cease-fire agreement and has certainly been very well understood since as a result of detailed conversations that have taken place with the BRA about the nature of this exercise and the nature of Australia's role in it.

As I have said publicly in this Senate, it is only on the basis of a clear understanding by the BRA of Australia's involvement that we would ever become involved, because we are not in the business of trying to impose ourselves in an unhelpful way on this situation. Our intentions are wholly constructive and, in the way this has evolved so far, I think the effect has been wholly constructive. At this stage we do not know what the outcome of this process will be during this week; we can only hope that the process that has been set in train, the confidence-building mechanisms associated with it and the security supplied for it, will all work their effect and create an environment in which the obvious desire of the people for peace can be translated into some formal and final agreement, or some peace agreement which gives us all hope that this issue can be resolved.

I do not think it is helpful for Senator Margetts or anyone else to be proceeding in the way she has in that question, on a presumption of failure so far as this process is concerned; or on a presumption of bad faith by Australia or anyone else involved in it. What this process needs at the moment is an injection of confidence, not an injection of cynicism, scepticism and rank despair of the kind Senator Margetts has communicated in her question. There is no basis for it in terms of the way in which we or anyone else have been trying to handle this problem. The best thing she and her colleagues can do is—for once in their lives—demonstrate a little enthusiasm for a peace process that is now genuinely at work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Foreign Affairs would surely admit that the perceptions of parties involved in any peace process are as important as anything else in this type of process. The fact that Australia is seen by one of the important people in this process as not being a neutral party would mean surely that the role of support or facilitator does not apply. The support or facilitator role means that both parties agree to that role. Would the minister agree that all parties have not agreed that Australia is a neutral player in this process?

—All parties have agreed to Australia playing the role that I have described in this particular case, which is as a neutral facilitator of this particular process and which is not as a party on the ground, supplying armed personnel, playing the security role, but simply a role as logistic support for that—as the transporter, as the supplier, of those particular troops. It is because of the whole background to this affair that we have constantly accepted that it would be inappropriate for us to be present in force on the ground, not because we accept any responsibility for what has occurred but because we are conscious of that very factor of perceptions that Senator Margetts referred to.

PARA.TAB: The way in which we have handled this matter and been responsive to the requests from Sir Julius Chan and the other governments, the way in which we have been consulting with the other side to this debate and the way in which we have secured support from them, I think indicates that all the premises of Senator Margetts's question and her supplementary question are fundamentally flawed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. An internal Telecom report on service and fault performance has revealed that the telephone infrastructure in southern and western New South Wales is clapped out and poorly maintained. To quote from a report of Telecom's technical transmission group:

QUESTION.PARA: The existing rural telephone network is in very poor shape . . .
The existing rural telephone network is in very poor shape . . .
When will this Labor government direct Telecom to spend some of its reported $1.7 billion corporate profit on this second-rate phone service that country people have to put up with?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a particular brief on the concerns Senator Tierney might have about particular concerns in New South Wales. If there is something the minister wants to supply in response to those concerns, I will get him to do so. We all know that Telecom continues to have a very substantial investment program around the country. I do not think it should be a cause of concern to senators that it is getting a good return for taxpayers on their investment.

PARA.TAB: Public enterprise cannot win. When it delivers a good return on investment, it gets criticised. When it does not, it gets criticised. I think we have a situation where Telecom is a good investment. That is why those on the other side are so enthusiastic about selling it and why we are not going to. Telecom has reported a strong growth, it has increased revenues and it has contained its costs. This has led to increased dividend payments to the Commonwealth, which I think we would all welcome. I am not aware of it being in any way generated by a decline in Telecom's investment activity. If the minister wants to add anything to that, I will get him to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. We all welcome profit from public enterprise but we also welcome community service obligation, particularly for the bush. To quote what is wrong with the service in the bush:

QUESTION.PARA: The servicing of the network investigated is totally understaffed . . . There are no reliable records kept of completed repairs . . . Faults are not being repaired at all, the service restoration method is to transpose around the problem . . . There is a zero level of field staff understanding of the transmission testing techniques and operating principles . . . Modern testing equipment although adequately supplied, is only used by a minority of staff . . .
When will rural people get some of this $1.7 billion and have the money spent on universal service in rural areas, as is the obligation of the government?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a desperate effort to have it both ways. Those opposite say, `We do not in any way mind this profit,' but then they want to work out how it ought to be spent other than in the way determined by the members of the board of Telecom, who are appointed for just that purpose. In my understanding, we have a very substantial amount of infrastructure investment going on in the Australian telecommunications industry, and many Australians are getting a very good service because of that. We find that the measurement of telecommunications service to consumers in Australia gives Telecom a very solid vote of support as a high quality service provider. That does not mean there are no problems. As I said before, if the minister wants to add something with regard to the specific matters raised by Senator Tierney, I will forward it to Senator Tierney.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray. I ask the minister: has he seen the press release from the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations concerning the unfair treatment of people seeking to enlist in the armed forces in relation to testing for HIV? Can the minister advise the Senate of the government's policy on allowing people with HIV to enlist in the armed forces?

—Let me say at the outset that the ADF HIV policy was developed after extensive consultation between the Australian defence forces and AIDS experts, including NACAIDS, the AIDS task force, and the Department of Human Services and Health. Contrary to the press release, when ADF members are found to be HIV positive their future employability is determined on a case by case basis; we simply do not throw them out on the street.

PARA.TAB: However, it is not possible for such members to continue to be employed in some operational areas for a number of reasons. For instance, in the case of the navy, many countries, including the United States, simply will not allow HIV positive personnel to enter their ports. It is also the case that the physical, mental and environmental stresses that occur in many operational positions can be expected to aggravate existing medical conditions.

We do try to look at alternative areas in which to employ HIV positive members to enable them to continue in the service of the Australian Defence Force. Where this is not possible, every effort is made to support their reintegration into the community. In that regard the department is developing a new retraining package under the direction of my colleague Gary Punch. The ADF also provides counselling to those members on the medical consequences of their illness and assists them with developing a regime for maintaining good health.

On the substantive question of rejecting recruits who test positive for HIV, we have no intention of changing the existing policy. We do not accept applicants who test positive to hepatitis A, B or C, or many other medical conditions. Let me finally say that the comments by the Disability Commissioner prejudging the issue I regard as very regrettable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Collins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. There are six rural land protection board districts in New South Wales—Mudgee, Merriwa, Dubbo, Scone, Nyngan and Grafton—all of which qualify for the Prime Minister's drought package according to the Rural Assistance Authority in New South Wales. Why have they been denied access to the Prime Minister's exceptional circumstances assistance?

—The facts are that they do not. I am pleased that Senator Brownhill has given me the opportunity to say a few words about this because the actions that the New South Wales minister for agriculture, Mr Causley, took in raising the hopes of people without foundation are regrettable, and I think `regrettable' would be a polite word for it. I have been extremely polite over the last couple of weeks, actually, about Mr Causley. I know he has an election to face—
—It is his own electorate.

—Yes, that is right. I know that he was concerned about his own electorate, which in fact was the one district, can I say—not six districts—that last week we got down to arguing about. There was no argument at official level on the clear ineligibility of five of those six districts that were on a draft list. They did not qualify for the 24 out of 36 qualification; in fact, they came nowhere near it.

PARA.TAB: The integrity of this very substantial package of assistance has to be defended, not just in the farming community but elsewhere in the Australian community. The only way it can be defended is if the guidelines set up are adhered to. These were the guidelines that not only were agreed at the ARMCANZ meeting but, at Mr Causley's insistence, we actually shook hands on—24 out of 36. The original guidelines provided for two years of continuous drought.

As I said publicly at the time, they would have been totally defendable criteria to use for the benefits of this significant package—two years. I do not think that anyone would argue that one year of drought would be an extreme drought. I have changed the drought guidelines that apply to Queensland. Had the original guidelines been applied to New South Wales—they were criteria suggested by the shadow minister and I quoted from his press conference on the drought—six rural districts in New South Wales would have qualified. I deliberately revised those guidelines from two years continuous drought to 24 months out of 36 to assist farmers in New South Wales—that is, any 24 months out of the previous 36. That was to cater for farmers who had dry years in 1991 and 1992 and are currently droughted, but actually had good crops last year. This will allow them still to qualify. The opposition's proposed definition would have provided for six districts to be assisted; we are providing for 15 districts in New South Wales to receive assistance under the amended criteria.

I made public last week that we provided a draft list to New South Wales officials. I am sure that Senator Brownhill would concede that a lot of work has had to be done on this package. We have had to line up a whole lot of social security officers very quickly indeed to handle a whole new form of payment from today on to get the money out. We have had to draft a whole stack of legislation. A lot of work has been done—and I must say cooperatively.

A draft list was issued at official level with the word `draft' stamped on it in letters an inch high. I am happy to table that draft. Mr Causley faxed that list to his National Party mates and media outlets all across New South Wales. We know where it came from because we see `Minister for Agriculture' at the top of the fax.

A lot of people in crisis were hanging on every word that came from the governments of New South Wales and the Commonwealth. For a minister to fax out a draft list which had not been confirmed by either the New South Wales government or the Commonwealth was indeed a cruel thing to do. That list was revised. I asked my department to triple-check all the draft listings, and a small number were removed. I condemn the minister for agriculture in New South Wales for circulating this list to his National Party mates and to a number of media outlets in New South Wales. That is how this list was circulated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In answer to an earlier question, the minister said that exceptional circumstances are applied where the drought has gone beyond people's ability to cope. If there has been drought in 24 of the last 41 months, one is aware that it has gone beyond a farmer's capability to cope. When will the government understand that this drought is really crippling people? People are being forced to sell or shoot their breeding herds, so when will the government do something to help such people?

—This package is targeted at people who need the help most. There was no argument at the ARMCANZ meeting from state or federal ministers, irrespective of their political persuasion, that this money is going to the correct place—Queensland and northern New South Wales. I repeat that it was appallingly irresponsible for the minister for agriculture in New South Wales to circulate to media outlets and to National Party members, who then put out press statements, a list that has stamped on it, in letters an inch high, the word `Draft'. That was an appalling piece of irresponsibility. I condemn the minister for agriculture in New South Wales for doing so.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite should talk to the shadow minister. He said that this list with the six districts on it was `circulated in New South Wales'. It was, but it was not circulated by me; it was circulated by the minister for agriculture in New South Wales. That is where John Anderson should take his complaint. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. I refer to the good fortune of American citrus growers who continue to enjoy between 40 and 47 per cent protection against Brazilian orange juice concentrate while Australia, according to the government, must dismantle its sales tax concession for local content. Why did the government cut Australian tariff protection against imported fruit juice concentrates to the ridiculously low level of 10 per cent, reducing further to five per cent, when it must have been aware that the Uruguay Round of GATT would demolish protection through the sales tax system? Secondly, what does the government intend to do to help the Australian citrus industry remain viable now that its complete lack of foresight has put our growers at risk?

—It is rather sad. The Australian Democrats were starting to establish a little credibility around the place for putting forward economically coherent proposals; now they are back to their bad old ways. In fact, they were starting to take the place of this useless lot opposite as the people who articulated alternative economic positions. But here we have them going back to their bad old days—getting their facts confused and using that jumble of facts as a launching pad for a series of unrelated assertions that are counterproductive.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I want to put some facts on the table and then point out some of the contradictions. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is exactly that: an agreement. We cannot impose it on other people. We all have to agree. It is not an Australian edict that we tell everybody else what they have to do; it is an agreement. That agreement distinguishes between tariff—that is, border protection measures which say that things cannot come in—and discrimination within countries; what is called national treatment.

A product brought into a country must be treated the same irrespective of its country of origin. Australia is a great beneficiary of that rule—including our citrus growers, who export about $84 million around the world. We protest when other people around the world discriminate against our products. We cannot have it both ways. We cannot go around the world protesting about discrimination against us and then seek to discriminate against others. We cannot have it both ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —America does.
—No, it does not. It has tariff protection. I want to come to the Democrats' view about tariff protection in a moment. Firstly, I am trying to distinguish between those two principles.

PARA.TAB: I want to put forward a fact in response to Senator Spindler's third point before I come back to the Democrats' view about advocacy of higher tariffs. The government will shortly respond to an important report by the horticultural task force. In that response we will determine what measures we will take to improve the international competitiveness of the citrus industry in response to the matters that have arisen under GATT and other measures.

I want to explain to the Democrats a bit of basic arithmetic. It does not make sense to pose here as opponents of indirect tax and advocates of tariffs. A tariff on orange juice puts up the price of orange juice. The Democrats are opposed to indirect taxes because they put up the price of essentials. They spent the whole of the last election purporting to agree with us that they do not like indirect taxes because they put up the price of basic essentials. But here they are wanting higher tariffs on orange juice and higher tariffs on clothes, which will mean that the price of food and clothing will be more expensive. They cannot at the same time credibly hold both those positions. It is in fact against the interest of the Australian primary producers to do it, and they do not want it done. It is against the interest of Australian consumers, and they do not want it done. It is just another part of the myth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What price is orange juice going to be?

—The Democrats are going to make orange juice more expensive. They do not like the tariffs coming down, and that is what will put up the price. I read Senator Kernot's confused speech. Reiterating it here will not make it make any more sense. We will be giving consideration to the report in determining how we might best deal with this matter, but it will not be by putting up the price of orange juice by increasing tariffs.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister says that we all benefit tremendously through GATT. That is fine. But why should the citrus growers pay the price? If we are going to benefit to the tune of $4 billion, out of which the government is going to derive considerable revenue, there should be sufficient funds available to assist the citrus industry. The minister has not answered the last part of my question. What is he going to do specifically to assist Australian citrus growers?

—I appreciate that Senator Spindler likes asking questions and not listening to answers, because I specifically referred to that part of his question. There has been a report from the horticultural task force on these and other matters. That report will go to cabinet shortly and we will announce the policy that flows from it.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) on 24 March this year, I agreed to ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to re-examine the application of section 53 of the constitution concerning the Senate's authority to amend proposed laws relating to a proposed charge or burden. I now have a copy of a letter from the Attorney-General to the Hon. George Gear MP, Assistant Treasurer, dealing with this matter, and I hereby table it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day, relating to the purchase of real estate by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to my question, Senator Evans chose not to ask Mr Keating to explain how he could afford to buy a Woollahra mansion for $2.2 million, which is more than the total take-home pay the Prime Minister has earned during his 25 years as a parliamentarian.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that this chamber—in fact, the people of Australia—would like to know how Mr Keating has been able to avoid the effects of the `recession we had to have', that is, his recession, in which tens of thousands of ordinary Australians have lost their homes and businesses, particularly those in rural Australia, who note the extraordinary difference between the treatment of Mr Keating's piggery group where $4 1/2 million was provided for as a bad debt by the Commonwealth Bank, while at the same time the Commonwealth Bank appeared to be enthusiastically putting other primary producers off their farms.

There is no doubt that the Prime Minister, as he promised in the 1989 budget, has brought home the bacon. He has brought home the bacon to himself and left the rest of the carcass very badly used for the rest of Australia. Continuing the analogy of bringing home the bacon, in order to get this sort of money he seems to have had some kind of snout in the trough. No doubt there will be enough room for many people at his Thai teak table. No doubt there will be plenty of room for French clocks and Gould prints in the Keating mansion. That is, of course, if he can magically find the money to borrow or acquire all these items, just as he managed to acquire his mansion.

We hear from Senator Gareth Evans today that all this is simply a commercial venture—that he bought it in order to lease it out at a very high rent. We know already that this was a mate's price when he bought it because the former owner said, `Really, it is worth a lot more than $2.2 million,' and that this was just a mate's price to the Prime Minister. Quite frankly, no Prime Minister should put himself in a position where he gets a special price for something, because that implies clearly some benefit to the Prime Minister—he is under some obligation.

If he managed to buy this mansion for a mate's price, we wonder what kind of a mate's lease will happen now. Will there be a mate's lease whereby someone pays some specially high leasing price, just as the Prime Minister paid a specially low purchase price? The Prime Minister should not be in a position where he would be under any such obligation, although I suppose that quite a few people would like to provide the Prime Minister with a benefit by paying him a handsome rent on his mansion because there are many matters where, in fact, people do stand to gain from governmental decisions.

It may well be, of course, that this special mate's rent is high enough for the Prime Minister even to avoid the need for negative gearing, because one gets negative gearing, which would quite properly and legally reduce one's tax liability, only where one's rent is lower than one's interest payments. It might be appropriate in these particular and extraordinary circumstances for the Prime Minister, when he does make such a lease, to advise the parliament of it and of the terms of it so there can be no suggestion of any kind of impropriety, any kind of mate's rate.

When one thinks of the times when the Prime Minister has criticised others—particularly those on this side—for having made quite proper arrangements with housing in order to minimise their tax liabilities by negative gearing, one finds it interesting to see whether this Prime Minister will admit, if it is the case, that he has negatively geared in, as I have said, a legally proper way to minimise his tax. He held himself up to be a puritan on the issue of tax when he attacked our former leader on this very issue. He said, `You can see that the tax I paid is totally correct and proper because it has been audited.' That was, in fact, false; it was his company that had been audited.

I conclude by saying that I wonder whether the Prime Minister remembers telling a Sydney journalist, Jonathon Chancellor, `All you write about is fascist types upgrading their property or flash eastern suburbs types driving around in their second-hand Mercedes dragging their mortgages behind them.' Now that Mr Keating is adding a big mortgage to his longstanding second-hand Mercedes—that is the one photographed in Warren Anderson's driveway—by upgrading his property to a $2.2 million mansion, under which category should the Prime Minister be listed—a fascist property upgrader or a flash eastern suburbs type?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Michael Baume raised is valid and important. A lot of Australians—particularly those in small business who lost a lot of money during the `recession that we had to have'—would be interested to find out the answer to that.
—Ha! How about the right to privacy?

—Senator Forshaw may laugh. Government senators may think it is appropriate for their leader to purchase a property worth $2.2 million and feel that this parliament and the people of Australia have no right to ask any questions about that, but I have to tell them that they are out of touch with most Australians. Most Australians are interested in answers to these questions. No wonder the government looks extremely embarrassed about it.

PARA.TAB: This is the member for Blaxland. This is the man who stands up day after day in this parliament and, among his other duties, represents the people of Blaxland. But will he live there? Does he want to mix with these people, or does he want to move to the leafy and prestigious suburb of Woollahra into his $2.2 million mansion? There are important issues of public interest involved here. In the Sydney Morning Herald today, Max Walsh said:

Mr Keating bought his present Elizabeth Bay house, which he has never occupied, in 1983 for $225,000. At the time this carried a substantial mortgage. Since then he has outlaid a considerable sum in renovations which are still incomplete. However, it would now bring—

SPEECH.PARA: apparently in a sale—
between $800,000 and $900,000 on the Sydney market.
The Prime Minister's salary is $211,000 a year, which means an after-tax income of $121,000. Max Walsh went on to say:
In other words, it would take every cent he is paid to cover the cost of servicing a mortgage that represented the shortfall between the cost of buying Woollahra and selling Elizabeth Bay.

PARA.TAB: The figures do not take into account other investments over the years by Mr Keating but they do illustrate his limited ability to service a significant debt from his cash flow as a politician.

SPEECH.PARA: Max Walsh then said:

PARA.TAB: On resignation, Mr Keating will be entitled to a big lump sum from the parliamentary superannuation scheme which would break the back of any increased mortgage payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating is probably the wealthiest Prime Minister in Australian history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Forshaw laughs, but the purchase of this property is a huge investment. Mr Keating, as government senators know, has been in parliament for a very long time. Senator Baume has raised some important questions in this parliament, questions to which the Australian public would like to receive some answers.

PARA.TAB: A lot of people on the government side would be interested to receive answers to these questions. At the very least, perhaps Mr Keating might decide to convene a seminar which we can all go along to and at which he can tell us how we can all become extremely wealthy on an MP's salary. I put it to honourable senators that that would be a particularly interesting seminar. In conclusion, let me say that Senator Baume has raised an important issue today and we are yet to receive a satisfactory answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleague Senator Kemp in putting to the Senate that the questions raised by my colleague Senator Baume were proper questions and ones that are deserving of answers. But instead we got the invective and abuse that have become the trademark of the future member for Holt.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that the people of Australia are entitled to know how somebody who has supposedly lived on a parliamentary salary for 25 years has the unique capacity, all of a sudden, to purchase a $2.2 million residence. If it is from other incomes earned, so be it, but then let him disclose it on the public register, as is required of other parliamentarians. If it is on the basis that he has borrowed moneys against his prospective superannuation payout, then let him say so publicly because we know that that would be in breach of Commonwealth laws.

It might also indicate what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) intends to do in the very near future—possibly make way for the future member for Holt, we do not know. But how is he going to pay off this loan over a period of four or five years, if indeed there is a substantial loan? There would be a cash flow problem in the meantime. One wonders with this major property purchase whether the Prime Minister relied on his factional colleague from New South Wales Senator Stephen Loosley, who has this unique capacity to buy million dollar properties, but then of course to resell them at a loss. I trust that the Prime Minister did not rely on Senator Loosley's advice.

Then, of course, the other possibility is that Senator Chris Evans arranged a loan for the Prime Minister. He seems to have a history of providing loans for certain people in the Australian Labor Party who are in financial strife. Of course, either of those scenarios relying on his Labor Party colleagues would be of concern to the people of Australia. The question has to be asked: how does he fund it, how does he pay off the loan, and how does he indeed pay the interest payments? They are serious questions relating to matters of proper concern and should be answered.

If Mr Keating inherited the money, let him say so; if he won the money, let him say so. All that Senator Baume is seeking is an explanation. The concern expressed by the opposition, by the media and I am sure by a lot of ordinary Labor voters is valid. Until the Prime Minister comes clean on the issue, it will remain a valid concern. There is no doubt that on 25 years of parliamentary salary the Prime Minister could not afford this house. Therefore, there must be some other source of funding which has not been disclosed to the people of Australia. Indeed, in the past the Labor Party has prided itself on public disclosure and the fact that people should not have anything to hide. But of course when the acid test is on the Prime Minister himself and the Labor Party, all of a sudden they do not want to answer the questions which are quite properly raised by my colleague Senator Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow my colleague Senator Panizza regarding the reply given by Senator Gareth Evans today at question time. Senator Evans may have believed, as he often does when he answers the questions, that that is all it takes, the standard reply, and he will carry the government's argument on the day. —I am very touched that you have noticed.

The market reaction has been very cutting and very deep, because there is now a newly coined phrase going around the marketplace. Talk about perceptions cutting deep now—the marketplace is coining the phrase `the dynamic inconsistency'. That means the capacity of this government to tell lies.

PARA.TAB: It is not going to say that straight out, of course. It coins this nebulous economic term, `dynamic inconsistency'. This dynamic inconsistency is now being factored into economic decisions in the marketplace—in particular, of course, by the bond dealers. So the government has to come to grips with this new phenomenon—that the marketplace simply does not believe the government's statements anymore. I do not say the statements are coming from the Treasury, because the Treasury has taken the line of the markets; nor are they coming from the Reserve Bank. Even the former prime ministerial economics adviser, Professor Barry Hughes, who now works for First Boston, has dropped the government. He has been a well-known supporter—although not quite an apologist; I give him more professional credit than that—and defender, as best he can, of government policy.
