DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Hon. Sir Nigel Hubert Bowen AC, KBE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 27 September 1994, of the Hon. Sir Nigel Hubert Bowen AC, KBE, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Parramatta from 1964 to 1973, Attorney-General from 1966 to 1969 and in 1971, Minister for Education and Science from 1969 to 1971, Minister for Foreign Affairs from 1971 to 1972, and former Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia from 1976 to 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Tuesday, 27 September 1994, of the Hon. Sir Nigel Hubert Bowen AC, KBE, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Parramatta from 1964 to 1973, Attorney-General from 1966 to 1969 and in 1971, Minister for Education and Science from 1969 to 1971, Minister for Foreign Affairs from 1971 to 1972, and former Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia from 1976 to 1990, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Nigel Hubert Bowen was born on 26 May 1911 at Summerland, British Columbia. He came to Australia as a young boy, was educated at King's School, Parramatta, and studied law at St Paul's College, Sydney University. He was admitted to the New South Wales bar in 1936 and later to the Victorian bar. With the advent of World War II he enlisted in the Australian Military Forces in 1941, before transferring to the Second AIF in 1942. He served in the South Pacific region for two years, then transferred to the Reserves in 1946 with the rank of captain. Sir Nigel resumed his legal career and took silk in 1953. He spent some time as President of the New South Wales Bar Council and from 1957 to 1960 held the post of Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia.

PARA.TAB: In 1963, Sir Nigel stood for, and won, the seat of Parramatta, which had been vacated by the resignation of Sir Garfield Barwick. In 1966, building on his already distinguished and successful legal career, he was appointed Attorney-General in the Holt ministry. He served in this portfolio in successive ministries until November 1969, making a brief return to the portfolio in 1971. From 1969 to 1971 he was Minister for Education and Science and from 1971 to 1972 he was Foreign Minister in the McMahon government. His parliamentary record shows that he also led numerous delegations on visits within Australia and overseas.

Sir Nigel left the parliament in 1973 to take up an appointment as Chief Judge in Equity in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. This was followed by his appointment in 1976 as the first Chief Judge—later Chief Justice—of the then newly created Federal Court of Australia, a position he held with distinction until his retirement in 1990.

It was in that capacity as Chief Judge of the Federal Court that I had a great deal, personally, to do with Sir Nigel when I was Attorney-General in 1983-84. I have to say that I have nothing but the fondest memories of those encounters. He was a tough advocate for his court, as he had been for his clients at the bar, but he was always a charming, gentlemanly and wholly constructive person to deal with, never losing sight of the public policy goals that we were mutually trying to achieve in judicial administration at that time.

His appointment to set up and head the new Federal Court was a particularly appropriate culmination to Sir Nigel's public career, as he had long perceived the need for the establishment of a Commonwealth superior court below the High Court. Indeed, it was Sir Nigel who as Attorney-General in 1968 first introduced a bill for the establishment of such a court. Although that bill was not proceeded with, it provided much of the foundation for the Federal Court of Australia Act that was eventually passed in 1976.

In setting up the Federal Court, Sir Nigel was responsible for much of the procedural innovation for which the court is still highly regarded. He also played a significant part in developing the court's approach to the Commonwealth's administrative law jurisdiction, an area of the law in which Sir Nigel had a great interest. As Attorney-General in 1968, he had initiated the inquiry undertaken by the Commonwealth Administrative Review Committee. That committee's report in 1971 formed the basis for the many remarkable developments in administrative law that took place later in the decade: the establishment of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; the setting up of the Commonwealth Ombudsman; and the passage of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. A true Australian, it was also Sir Nigel who, with the Privy Council (Limitation of Appeals) Act 1968, began the process of making the High Court the final court of appeal in Australia.

Sir Nigel will also be remembered for his chairing of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest which was established in February 1978 and reported in July 1979. The Bowen committee's report was an extremely thorough piece of work, reflecting Sir Nigel's very sound judgment. Over the years the report has become an authoritative source for dealing with the various ethics and conflict of interest issues which parliamentarians, judicial and statutory office-holders and public servants have to address from time to time.

Sir Nigel Bowen was a hard working and dedicated man who served the Australian people outstandingly well in both his legal and political careers. In recognition of his great service to Australia, he received a knighthood in 1976 and in 1988 was appointed a Companion of the Order of Australia, one of Australia's highest awards, for his services to the law. He will be sadly missed by all who knew him and who admired his contribution to Australian public life. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife Ermyn and his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in expressing regret at the death of Sir Nigel Bowen and extend condolences to his wife and three daughters and to their families. We are saddened by his death. His was a long and distinguished career. Sir Nigel was an eminent lawyer and an able parliamentarian who was a minister under three Liberal prime ministers: Harold Holt, John Gorton and William McMahon.

PARA.TAB: He contested the leadership of the parliamentary Liberal party after the McMahon government lost office in 1972, to lose by only one vote to Billy Snedden. Sir Nigel returned to his first love, the law, a year afterwards. He resigned from parliament to become a judge of appeal at the New South Wales Supreme Court. He subsequently became Chief Judge in Equity and, in 1976, the first Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia, a position which he held with distinction for 14 years until he retired in 1990. He was made a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1976 and was awarded the Companion of the Order of Australia in 1988.

Sir Nigel was born in 1911 and educated at the King's School and Sydney University. He was admitted as a solicitor in 1934 and to the New South Wales bar two years later. He served in the 2nd AIF and reached the rank of captain before he was discharged and returned to the bar. In 1946 he became the editor of the Australian Law Journal, a position he filled for the next 12 years. He became a Queen's Counsel in New South Wales in 1953 and in Victoria in the following year. He was President of the New South Wales Bar Council from 1959 to 1961 and Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia from 1957 to 1960.

Sir Nigel entered parliament as the member for Parramatta in 1964 after the resignation of another eminent jurist and contemporary, Sir Garfield Barwick. Like Sir Garfield, Sir Nigel embarked on a political career relatively late in his professional life and, like Sir Garfield, held the portfolios of Attorney-General and foreign affairs. In Sir Nigel's first term as Attorney-General he initiated the abolition of appeals to the Privy Council. He was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs by Harold Holt 2 1/2 years after entering parliament and filled that position for several years.

Prime Minister Gorton appointed him Minister for Education and Science, a portfolio he held from late 1969 to early in 1971 when he was again appointed Attorney-General by Prime Minister McMahon. He held the portfolio for only five months before being appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs. As foreign affairs minister, Sir Nigel identified and articulated the emerging importance of Australia's relationship with Asia. In June of 1972 Sir Nigel was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We are geographically very close to Asia and our future is very largely with the future of the countries in this region.

Sir Nigel played a leading role in galvanising international opinion in the Pacific basin against the atmospheric testing of nuclear weapons and led a push for Australia to gain membership of the United Nations Security Council. Sir Nigel said:

The extent to which we've been making our own decisions has been underestimated. If we find ourselves going along the same line as Britain or the U.S., it doesn't mean we are dancing to their tune. It means we have made a judgment and decided to do so. You make an independent judgment, but you don't make a fetish of being independent.
It was a sensible and quite enlightened position for the time. Sir Nigel remained as foreign minister until a change of government 16 months later.

PARA.TAB: As my friend John Mansfield QC, President of the Law Council, said in a tribute to Sir Nigel, he gave the Federal Court `immense standing' and saw it become a court of great eminence. Mr Mansfield also said that Sir Nigel was a lawyer of great learning, yet a modest man of the utmost courtesy, spoken of fondly by all who knew him. Again, I offer sincere condolences to Lady Bowen and Sir Nigel's family.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wish to be associated with this condolence motion before the Senate and to make a few brief remarks. Although Sir Nigel Bowen was not known to me personally, he was by all accounts a much admired man as well as a politician who commanded respect from many quarters. His contributions to public life extended over a great many years and involved service in both the Gorton and McMahon coalition governments. His entry into politics was preceded by a distinguished legal career. It is clear that this remained his great professional passion in life, as he chose to devote himself to law after he left politics.

PARA.TAB: Among the highlights of Sir Nigel's early career in the law, his period as editor of the Australian Law Journal deserves to be recognised. It was noted by his peers of the time and by the present day Law Council of Australia that he served in this position with considerable distinction. Other notable highlights of his early career in the law included his appointment as a Queen's Counsel in the early 1950s and his terms as President of the New South Wales Bar Council from 1959 to 1961 as well as Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia from 1957 until 1960.

Nigel Bowen took on a parliamentary career at the by-election for the federal seat of Parramatta in 1964. As has been noted, this seat was formerly held by another equally notable Liberal member in Sir Garfield Barwick. Nigel Bowen served as the member for Parramatta until 1973. During his career in federal parliament, Sir Nigel Bowen distinguished himself by ministerial service in a number of key policy areas at the time, including holding the portfolios of education, science, Attorney-General and foreign affairs.

It was perhaps during his period as Attorney-General that Nigel Bowen made his greatest contributions to the development of public policy. It is certainly true that his own insights into the legislative process and the operations of the legal system were instrumental in his decisions to develop and later introduce a process of meaningful reform in the area of administrative law.

Nigel Bowen was also responsible as Attorney-General for the decision to establish a new level of Australian legal jurisdiction in the Federal Court. The decision to establish the Federal Court was as much related to the government's view that the High Court needed relief from an increasing volume of litigation as it was to Nigel Bowen's own view that the High Court should be freed up to fulfil its original role as the place where the Australian constitution is ultimately interpreted. It should also be noted that Nigel Bowen was responsible for the initiative during his term as Attorney-General to abolish appeals to the Privy Council.

Although his term as Minister for Foreign Affairs was a relatively short one, I note that Nigel Bowen had the foresight during his ministry to propose a number of initiatives that would put an end to nuclear testing in the Pacific. His work in this area deserves to be recognised here today, and on behalf of the Australian Democrats I would take this opportunity to acknowledge his leadership in an area where public sentiment was already progressing well ahead of established view in the international community.

His many significant years of service as a federal government minister were, of course, partly responsible for Nigel Bowen's being recognised publicly when he was awarded a knighthood, in the form of a KBE, in 1976. Much later in life Sir Nigel Bowen received another equally deserved accolade in the form of a Companion of the Order of Australia, in 1988. This latter citation recognised Nigel Bowen's post-political career, which itself was equally notable and included appointments as a Chief Judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and then later as Chief Justice of the Federal Court, a position he held until his retirement in 1990. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I offer his family our deepest sympathies at this time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government. Sir Nigel Bowen had a long and distinguished career in federal politics and law. He held eminent positions in both professions and will be particularly remembered for his far-reaching reforms in the area of federal administrative law.

PARA.TAB: Sir Nigel was born in Canada in 1911. He was educated at the King's School, Parramatta, before attending the University of Sydney, where he studied arts and law. After graduation he embarked on his first career and practised as a solicitor for several years before gaining admission to the bar of New South Wales in 1936.

During the Second World War Sir Nigel served in the 2nd AIF until 1946. He then transferred to the officers' reserve, having attained the rank of captain. Sir Nigel resumed his practice at the bar and was appointed QC in 1953.

During his years at the bar, Sir Nigel was President of the New South Wales Bar Association from 1959 to 1960 and Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia from 1957 to 1960. He served as general editor of the Australian Law Journal for 12 years from 1946 to 1958. He also found time to lecture in company law and taxation at the University of Sydney Law School.

In 1964 Sir Nigel moved from law into federal politics when he won the seat of Parramatta, succeeding Sir Garfield Barwick. Despite a relatively late entry into federal politics at the age of 53, Sir Nigel served nine years as the Liberal member for Parramatta, during which he undertook two terms as Attorney-General from 1966 to 1969 and again in 1971. He then was education and science minister from 1969 to 1971 and Minister for Foreign Affairs from 1971 to 1972.

As Attorney-General, Sir Nigel was instrumental in securing the passage of several historic pieces of legislation that have provided the framework for our modern system of federal administrative law. One of these was the Privy Council (Limitation of Appeals) Act 1968, which established the High Court as the final court of appeal for all constitutional cases and federal legislation by abolishing appeals to the Privy Council.At that time only appeals on state matters could then be taken through to the Privy Council. He was also responsible for introducing legislation dealing with trade practices and copyright.

As foreign affairs minister, Sir Nigel was equally forward-thinking in his outlook, declaring that Australia's future lay with Asia rather than with the European Community. During his parliamentary career Sir Nigel led several important parliamentary delegations. These included head of delegation of the United Nations international conference on human rights, head of delegation to the UNESCO conference on cultural policy, and head of the Australian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in 1972.

In July 1973, Sir Nigel departed federal politics and returned to the profession he called his first love—to take up a position as judge on the New South Wales Court of Appeal. In 1976 he was appointed Chief Judge, now known as Chief Justice, of the newly-created Federal Court of Australia. He filled this position with great eminence for 14 years, until his retirement in 1990.

Sir Nigel's overlapping careers in law and federal politics spanned a staggering 55 years. His enormous contribution to public life was recognised when he was awarded a knighthood in 1976 and Companion of the Order of Australia in 1988. Sir Nigel's reforms to federal administrative law were far-reaching, and his contribution to the Australian legal system will be lasting. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Sir Nigel Bowen's family and friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to join in this condolence motion. I had the honour, as the senior senator from New South Wales, to represent the President at Sir Nigel Bowen's funeral on Saturday. The Hon. Bob Ellicott, another former Attorney-General, gave an outstanding eulogy at that ceremony, and I am indebted to him for some of the information I wish to present to the Senate today.

PARA.TAB: As we have already heard, Sir Nigel was born in May 1911 in British Columbia, Canada, of an English mother and a Welsh father. The family then moved to Australia, where his father bought a sheep property near Gunnedah. Nigel's brother Brian was born there in 1912 but, when drought brought this endeavour to an end around 1915, his father wisely decided to take up again what he knew best—accountancy—and the family moved to Ashfield in Sydney, where his youngest brother, John, was born in 1916.

From 1922 to 1927 he attended the King's School at Parramatta. These were not easy financial times but, with the help of a scholarship, the fifth form prize and a university exhibition, he completed his schooling and moved on to complete arts and law degrees with distinction at the University of Sydney. He also won an exhibition to St Paul's College.

He not only had a distinguished academic career but also was a keen sportsman. He played cricket for St Paul's firsts, and first grade university rugby as scrum-half. He even tried his hand at boxing. It pointed out one of the great qualities of his life: he was a born all-rounder.
After graduating with second class honours in law, he completed his articles and became a solicitor at Sly and Russell. In 1936 he was admitted to the bar.

World War II was another challenge he met, exhibiting the high qualities of leadership and community service which marked the whole of his life. After war broke out he enlisted in the AIF, trained with the 3rd Armoured Regiment and was selected to undertake an intelligence officers course before being chosen to become a member of staff with the First Australian Army Headquarters in Brisbane, where he rose to the rank of captain.

Late in 1943, Major Mitchell, who had been commissioned to establish a new water transport unit to be known as the No. 43 Landing Craft Company, sought and obtained the then Captain Bowen's posting as second-in-command and adjutant of the new unit. After training, the new unit distinguished itself in the task of inshore supply and the provision of mobility in the roadless north of Papua New Guinea during the jungle campaigns of the war. In March 1945 Captain Bowen led a dangerous reconnaissance expedition among hazardous reefs to the water off enemy-held territory west of Wewak to determine whether a landing craft base could be established there.

No. 43 Landing Craft Company had within its ranks an unlikely trio—Captain Nigel Bowen, Captain Frank Packer and Corporal Ninian Stephen. It was quite a company! Demobilised in February 1946, he resumed practice and in 1947 he married Eileen, who had been an army nurse and whom he loved dearly throughout her life.

From early 1951 Bob Ellicott, eventually to become another Attorney-General, read with Nigel Bowen and for a long time shared his and other chambers on the second floor of Denman Chambers, a very interesting floor that included Whitlam, Kerr and Wootten. Nigel Bowen took silk in 1953, and by 1959 had become a leading silk of the New South Wales bar and one of the leaders of the Australian bar.

He became President of the New South Wales Bar Association in 1959, and in 1960 Vice-President of the Law Council of Australia. In 1964 Garfield Barwick became Chief Justice and Nigel Bowen replaced him in the Commonwealth parliament as member for Parramatta—a seat which had been held successively by ministers of state: Sir Frederick Stewart, Sir Howard Beale and Sir Garfield. The then Mr Bowen did not break that chain.
He had a deep concern for the people and their welfare; for the rights of women and the individual's rights in the face of government. His political life bears testimony to all those things.

In December 1966 he became Attorney-General and immediately began a process of reform which reflected his fundamental political values. He thought it was time that the High Court became the ultimate court of appeal for Australia, and appeals were abolished from that court to the Privy Council. He established a committee under Sir John Kerr to report on a system of administrative review to protect the individual from Commonwealth bureaucracy, and a committee to reform the Judiciary Act to improve the federal system of justice.

People had been talking about a new federal court for years. He acted. He settled and introduced a bill to establish such a court. In November 1969, however, he left the office of Attorney-General and became Minister for Education and Science, an office which he held with distinction but only for a short period. In August 1971 he became foreign minister until the McMahon government lost office in 1972. As foreign minister he met with representatives of the People's Republic of China in Paris and recommended to Mr McMahon that recognition should take place. The Prime Minister, it is said, consulted the DLP and decided not to proceed.

In 1972 Nigel Bowen appointed a delegation to negotiate the seabed boundaries between the then Indonesian West Timor and north-west Australia. In October 1972 he signed the treaty which recognised and accepted Australia's rights to the bulk of this seabed. This and other initiatives he undertook on the law of the sea were of immense significance to Australia.

After the 1972 election many of his colleagues recognised his leadership potential. He stood for the position of Leader of the Opposition, but lost by one vote. How different the history of this country may have been had he won.

In politics both sides regarded him as a person of great quality and dignity. He did not engage in the game of rough, backroom, passageway politics—all too familiar to those who have been in this place. He emerged by the sheer quality and integrity of his personality as a leader among his peers. As Bob Ellicott said, he was a delightful colleague and his capacity was deeply missed by the parliament.

By 1973 he was 62 and he became successively a judge of the New South Wales Court of Appeal and Chief Judge in Equity where the quality and dominance of his intellect and his sense of justice were quickly recognised. In 1976, when the Hon. Bob Ellicott was Attorney-General, the Federal Court of Australia Act was passed. It was not without controversy because the court was seen by some as a threat to the state supreme courts. It was essential to find a chief justice whose administrative and intellectual capacity would ensure its success, so Mr Ellicott approached Nigel Bowen. Under his leadership the future of the court was assured.

He frequently sat in its appellate jurisdiction and, through his judgments, made significant contributions to the law it administered. Importantly, he was deeply involved in pioneering the implementation of the court's wide jurisdiction in trade practices and administrative law. His chief justiceship of the Federal Court was probably his greatest contribution to our national life—no doubt because he had the time to complete his task. The nation recognised his years of public service when he was created a Knight Bachelor and a Companion of the Order of Australia.
Nigel Bowen was a great Australian. He loved his family: his widow Ermyn and his daughters Pam, Dianne and Vivienne and his brother John, to whom we express our condolences.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their place.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licenses despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.

PETITION.PARA: apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and

PETITION.TITLE: Chemicals

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.

That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;

That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.

To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia rejects outright the Childcare Rebate Act 1993.
This Act:

PETITION.PARA: 1.fails to acknowledge the 45% of women who entered the workforce solely for economic reasons.
2.is inadequate in addressing equity in women and family choices.
3.does not recognise the value of unpaid work of a woman at home.
4.ignores the need for women with dependent children to be treated equally by way of a benefit replacing all other child related allowances and subsidies.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate repeal the Childcare Rebate Act 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.

(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage.
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australian Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore do we call upon the Senate to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:

PARA.TAB: (a) deplores the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and notes the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in 12 for Australian women;
(b) recognises the fact that breast cancer has the potential to affect every Australian family;
(c) recognises that there are inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners ask that the Senate call on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (a) increase funding for breast cancer research ten-fold (a minimum of $14 million) in the 1994/95 Budget; and
(b) consider further initiatives through the tax system to encourage donations for breast cancer research.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Criminal Code
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectively showeth that:

PARA.TAB: 1. We believe, the majority of Australians view homosexuality to be a gross perversion of nature.
2. We believe that any legislation which would allow acts of homosexuality, is against the best interests of the overwhelming majority of Australian citizens and,

3. That any action by the Federal Government to override Tasmania law with regard to sections 122 and 123 of the Tasmania Criminal Code, disregards the Sovereign right of an elected and democratic government to make laws for peace, order and good government of that State. PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners as in duty bound, therefore request that the House desist from any further attempts to override and negate Tasmania law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Government to take the necessary policy action to ensure Australia has sustainable economic and employment growth.

The Keating government is not only an arrogant government but also a complacent government. Arrogance and complacency are a lethal mix in their implications for all Australians. This government does not care about the enormous problems facing the Australian economy. This tired government does not give a damn for the damage that its complacency, arrogance and monumental incompetence heap on the Australian community, and particularly on the middle and lower income groups for whom it cruelly pretends to have concern and for whom it weeps crocodile tears.

PARA.TAB: The facts are irrefutable, and they are contained in the wording of this matter of urgency that I bring to the Senate on behalf of the Liberal-National Party opposition. This tired, arrogant, complacent, incompetent Keating Labor government has failed monumentally to take the policy actions necessary to ensure Australia's economic and employment growth is placed on a sustainable base in the future.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his team sit back smugly and say that they did enough in the 1980s and the early 1990s to enable Australia to grow into the 21st century. Indeed, the former industry minister, then Senator Button, said here in 1992 that there were no more reforms left for this government to tackle. Mr Keating even had the arrogance in his quite sanctimonious, self-indulgent, self-congratulatory speech to the recent Australian Labor Party national conference to assert that Labor had `earned the right to lead Australia into the next century.'

The real facts, not those of the Labor Party's Orwellian rewriters of history, are that Labor has indeed abdicated all right to lead Australia not only into the 21st century but as of this very day. Look at the facts—those which represent the symptoms of our deep-seated malaise: the first is that continuing massive unemployment is now still at almost 10 per cent compared with eight per cent in New Zealand, six per cent in the United States and only two to three per cent in countries such as Hong Kong and Singapore.

The second is the largest and most rapidly widening current account deficit of any OECD country—that is any Western nation—at over four per cent of GDP, and certain to finish the year much larger than that, compared with an average current account balance for all other OECD nations. Thirdly, there is the high cost of capital as reflected in our high real interest rates. Today, 10-year bonds in Australia now yield well over 10 per cent and real rates were around eight per cent in August compared with about 4 1/2 per cent in the United States, less than six per cent in New Zealand, 6.3 per cent in the UK and 4.1 per cent in Japan. Indeed, there are only two countries in the whole of the OECD area that have higher real interest rates than Australia.

Fourthly, there is low investment. Private fixed capital expenditure in Australia is still at near record lows. Last year Access Economics produced figures which showed Australia's capital stock was actually shrinking, so low was investment that it was not even keeping up with replacement levels. Last financial year it amounted to only 15.4 per cent of GDP, some 5 1/2 per cent lower than its recent peak of 19.8 per cent in 1988-89. Even if the government achieves its forecast of a 14 1/2 per cent increase in expenditure this financial year, it will still only equal 16.9 per cent—well down on most previous years.

Fifthly, low national savings: household savings are still at near record lows at around five per cent of GDP, while the public sector is dissaving to the tune of over four per cent of GDP. According to the ANZ bank's savings report, the last two quarters are the first two quarters of overall national saving in almost three years. We in fact had eight consecutive quarters of dissaving before these last two.

We do not have to have this situation. There are no immutable laws to say that we cannot compete in the world. We used to do so before this incompetent government came along. There are things that can be done to address our problems, to put Australia back on track, to compete with and to win against our international competitors; but we must take the initiative. We must have a government that governs in the national interest, not one that governs in the interests of its mates, as has been the hallmark of the Hawke and Keating Labor governments of the last 11 long years.

Let us look at some of those initiatives that should and indeed must be taken. Industrial relations reform: despite the general acceptance of the long overdue need for greater enterprise flexibility in the labour market this government, in cahoots with the ACTU leadership, has done everything it can to delay, disrupt and destroy attempts at genuine enterprise agreements—agreements that would leave all parties, employers, employees and the economy better off. But of course, Labor as the political wing of the labour movement, cannot cede power to the workers because if it did so the workers might realise what a waste the trade union leadership is and how it actually harms the workers' interests. This particular area of failed policy—industrial relations reform—is the worst example of sectional interest and power being put ahead of the national interest.

Secondly, Commonwealth-state financial relations: the issue of fair and equitable financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states is one where a cooperative and creative solution to the division of responsibilities between governments and the federation could very easily be agreed upon. But Prime Minister Keating is a natural centralist who trusts no-one else with power bar himself, and sometimes Bill Kelty. He could not stand the thought of the federation functioning effectively and efficiently because this would be anathema to his centralist predilections and obsessions.

Thirdly, micro-economic reform: the government's shipping deal with the maritime unions on the ANL question is another lost opportunity for competitive reform. The cosy deal that Prime Minister Keating and the MUA came to, whereby seamen will be exempt from income tax and the Commonwealth taxpayer will provide a guarantee for the ANL shipping line, is the worst kind of mates deal. There are many other areas of micro-economic reform also where the Commonwealth lags behind: privatisation of government-owned enterprises and service delivery; postal and telecommunications competition; taxation and corporations law simplification; national competition policy—the list goes on and on.

The hugely irresponsible budget deficit is more than $16 billion, when accounting fiddles are allowed for. As a result of Labor's huge and grossly irresponsible drain on national savings, Commonwealth debt will have risen from $30 billion in 1990 to a whopping $95 billion next year. At this stage there is still no sign of any move by the government to alter fiscal policy so that it actually starts to reduce that menacing debt burden. So Labor has fallen into a deeply complacent malaise in which it refuses even to recognise, let alone address, this nation's major problems.

There is much that can be done to reverse Australia's declining fortunes. The coalition's recently released directional statement entitled The Things That Matter contains a host of initiatives and goals to achieve that. I will just mention some of them. We can boost business investment by reducing the burden and complexity of capital gains tax, the superannuation guarantee levy, fringe benefits tax and other on-costs to business; by reducing government regulation and red tape; by maintaining a stable and predictable tariff reduction regime; and by reviewing anti-dumping procedures.

We can improve our productivity by empowering employees and employers to negotiate employment contracts directly and by encouraging employees to take a stake in their workplace and in many other areas. We can create jobs by ensuring that we have a vibrant, competitive small business sector and by revitalising the process of micro-economic reform, which creates secure long-term employment in internationally competitive firms. These initiatives provide a sound and an essential underpinning to Australia's future and, because they have not been pursued, the opposition has moved this motion of urgency on the government.

Every time they made speeches, they were about Fightback. They quoted this and that and said that this was what their policy approach would be. But where is The Things That Matter? We do not even hear the opposition mention it significantly in this place or in the media.
—Senator Short just mentioned it.

—It was hardly a glowing endorsement. The title might have got a run, but only once or twice. It is certainly significant to compare the approach of the opposition now, having lost the last election, with its approach prior to the last election. I suggest to the opposition that it is going from one extreme to the other. It has gone from a 600-odd policy document, developed by the leader largely in secret, to taking the approach that policy should not be developed because the electorate, according to the opposition, does not understand the policies when they are put forward.

—Senator Baume says we tell lies about them. I can recall debating the GST with Senator Baume on the radio. It was an interesting debate, but I do not recall any lies. The opposition will find out—and it has found it out election after election—that the electorate is not stupid. The people know what is fundamentally best for them. That was the bottom line approach of the electorate to Fightback at the last election. Ever since then the opposition's various frontbench spokespersons have been falling over themselves to bag Fightback and that approach.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the current state of the economy, we see a number of indicators—and a very broad range of indicators—that show that the economy is doing very well. I want to touch on a couple of the areas where Senator Short alleges there are particular problems. Firstly, housing activity is an important indicator of the economy. It remains around record levels. Despite a substantial increase in private dwelling approvals in August, there remains an expectation that dwelling sector activity is at or close to a peak. Pent-up housing demand is considered to be largely eroded, with current levels of building activity substantially higher than estimates of underlying demand.

The trend in private dwelling approvals increased by 2.1 per cent in August—the largest monthly increase since June 1992. In seasonally adjusted terms, private sector dwelling approvals increased by 15.4 per cent in August to reach their highest monthly level on record—and records began in January 1965. So that is one of the important indicators that things are going well.

In the retail trade, for example, current price retail trade data, seasonally adjusted, rose strongly in July following a marginal fall in June. I make this comment about monthly figures because I made it about a couple of the other indicators. We should always be cautious about descending to depths of gloom when one monthly set of figures trend down and reverting to a state of ecstasy when we see a significant increase in one month's figures. It is really the overall trend that is very important. Retail trade figures still remain strong and steady, and we have seen growth of seven per cent over the past 12 months in current price retail trade.

The Westpac Melbourne institute index of consumer confidence has fallen slightly, in seasonally adjusted terms in the last three months, by 8.6 per cent—below its peak of June 1994. Despite that, the general underlying consumer sentiment is still very high by historical standards. The index is 29 per cent higher than it was in September last year and one per cent higher than the peak of the late 1980s.

The various business surveys that are released indicate that business confidence has been sustained, following a June quarter that was fairly quiet in terms of business expectations. A strong improvement in output, sales, profitability and employment is anticipated in the September quarter by the National Australia Bank survey. Dun and Bradstreet report that profit expectations in the September quarter have reached their highest level in over five years. It also reports strong sales and employment expectations in the September quarter.

The ACCI Westpac report shows that manufacturing firms expectations for their general business outlook improved in the September quarter. The September quarter expectations for general business conditions, new orders and output all remain at or near historically high levels. The Australian Chamber of Manufacturers quarterly survey reports that manufacturers are expecting their strongest December quarter for at least the last five years. We only have to look at the headlines in the Australian Financial Review this morning. I do not think Senator Short has read them, given his contribution to this debate. Also, motor vehicle registrations in August were at their highest level since July 1990.

In respect of labour force data, I again stress the importance of being cautious about month to month figures. For example, employment fell in August, only very partly unwinding the exceptionally large increase reported in July. But in seasonally adjusted terms, there has been an increase in employment of 266,000 persons compared with a year ago, and over 60 per cent of the jobs created since August 1993 have been full time.

The government wants these figures to continue to improve. The unemployment rate is 9.5 per cent. We will get a new figure later in the week. I have to say that on the basis of today's ANZ bank job figures, it is probably likely that unemployment will continue to trend down. Job vacancies trends have continued to rise, with both the Department of Employment, Education and Training skill vacancy series and the ANZ series rising by around two per cent in August. The latest ANZ job advertisement figures released today show that job vacancies increased by four per cent in September.

I want to say something about inflation. I am scratching to think of any good points about the way in which the Fraser government handled inflation. It never got inflation under control. But today inflation in this country remains very low. In the June quarter inflation increased by 0.7 per cent and by 1.7 per cent in the year to June. Frankly, up until five or six years ago I was one of those who had given up on ever seeing inflation figures down around one or two per cent. Today there is an expectation that the inflation figure will be very low. The norm at the moment to have a very low inflation figure. Australia's inflation figure is certainly much lower than those of our major trading partners. The level of inflation is so important in terms of costs when we compete in the international marketplace.

The June quarter 1994 national accounts show that gross domestic product increased by 0.9 per cent in the quarter, following strong growth in the December and March quarters. The underlying strength in economic activity is reflected in through the year growth to June. Quarterly activity is growing at between 4 1/4 and 4 1/2 per cent seasonally adjusted. All the figures I have cited are good news figures. But what is the opposition's approach? The opposition, of course, picks the bad figures. It always tries to find the worst in a story. We get the same rhetoric about `cutting the deficit'. It has an ideological obsession with privatising everything and selling everything off.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do too.
—No, we do not have an obsession about it. We are selective, as is appropriate, with the degree to which we have public ownership. It is not in our platform.
—Everything has gone.

—I have just come from our national conference where I had a little bit to do with the airports resolution. We sit down and work out in a non-ideological and practical way what should be in government ownership and how it should be retained in government ownership, and what should not be. We have a clear policy position that we are not going to sell off water, Telecom or Australia Post. For a range of reasons, it is very important that those fundamental public services remain in public ownership.

PARA.TAB: I did not have any great ideological hassle about what we should do with airports. When I walk into an airport I do not get the thrill of socialism buzzing through my body. Our approach on this critical issue of privatisation is a practical one, not an ideological one.

I turn to the shipping arrangements entered into with ANL. Senator Short did not tell the whole truth when he said—I think these were his words—that the seamen were exempt from income tax. That is not correct. They still receive the same net income and they still have to pay tax in the same way. The relief is given to the shipping owners and operators, not to the individual seamen and I think it is a gross misstatement of the truth to imply otherwise.

This is not an unusual arrangement. In fact, it was an arrangement that was recommended as being necessary by the recent report of the inquiry into Australian shipping. If we want to continue to have some sort of Australian fleet, we have to preserve our competitiveness. This is a method that is adopted by a number of European nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was part of the package.
—It certainly was part of a package—a responsible package negotiated by a responsible minister.

PARA.TAB: In the time allocated to me in this debate I am not able to go through the impressive list of industrial relations and micro-economic reforms or to talk about the Hilmer report. TALK.START.PARA: —Worst balance of payments figures in the Western world.

—I agree with Senator Sherry that we should urge caution, but even if we urge caution we cannot deny that the figures at the moment are, in the main, looking pretty good. PARA.TAB: I am concerned that this government has failed to learn the lessons of the 1980s. If we are to have, even in its terms, a sustainable recovery, we need more active, imaginative and far-sighted economic policies. We need debate that includes hard and long-term decision making. But all we hear from the opposition is the mantra of `cut the deficit'. `What do we do about rising interest rates?—cut the deficit. What do we do about high unemployment?—cut the deficit. I think the problem with this overall debate is that the government has been let off the hook. Professor Galbraith's The culture of contentment prevails in this country, and both the major parties embrace essentially the same core economic policies. Overseas in Europe, America and East Asia the economic policy debates have moved on to look at the creative and positive role which government can play in restructuring and rebuilding economic structures, but not here. We in this country still believe that all the answers lie in a fundamentalist view of the markets and in economic rationalism.

It was interesting to note Vince Fitzgerald's comments last week that the Commonwealth government needs to look at reducing the deficit while maintaining a level of services that a civilised society expects and demands. This very day in this place the coalition will fail to vote with the Democrats to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for small business. So much for its support of that constituency! SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest rates are the blunt end of this government's economic policy. It is the blunt end that people feel around their ears when they try to pay off their homes; it is the blunt end that sends so many small businesses broke; it is the blunt end of Paul Keating's `recession we had to have' which destroyed so many people on the land. It was interest rates, a deliberate mechanism of government policy that has generated the massive unemployment, that made the recent years such a disaster for so many Australians.

PARA.TAB: The government got inflation down, at enormous cost, and it got interest rates down. But now what is happening in this economic recovery is a simple repetition of what we have seen repeatedly in the past. Interest rates are going up once again. The very instrument that destroyed so many Australians, destroyed so many small businesses, destroyed so many people's dreams is now on the way up again. That is not just a forecast, but interest rates have gone up. There are people putting their money where their judgment is, and that is in the futures market on bank bills. That judgment has already been made by people who in fact have to deal with money. Money is going to cost more—is now costing more—when we want to buy it and obtain it in future. That is the marketplace for money.

Paul Keating says they are wrong and, of course, everyone would believe Paul Keating. With his track record of economic advice to the marketplace and to Australians, naturally everyone would believe him. He was the man who said that economic problems were just that champagne was bubbling over the glass, that there would not be a recession, and so on, that we would not have a million unemployed. The fact is that the markets are more likely to be right and have a record of being right far more than our Prime Minister.

The problem is that in the absence of fiscal responsibility—and I say to Senator Kernot that that means being tough on government spending, spending by governments who reckon they know how to spend our money better than the people of Australia do—this government has imposed an absurd burden on interest rate policy. In other words, if we have very slack fiscal policy we have to have very tough interest rate policy, I just wonder whether this government—and particularly whether the Treasurer—is aware that the 90-day bank bill futures market is clearly the most accurate indicator of future moves in interest rates. I do not think that the Prime Minister is aware, because the government does not seem to know anything about the real world, that the futures market, which reflects the marketplace of money over the next 18 months or so, shows interest rates rising by about four percentage points from the beginning of last month. In fact, judging by the latest prices, it is up about an extra three per cent from now, but rising to around 10 per cent in 18 months time, indicating housing interest rates of course well above that level.

I wonder how realistic, for example, Senator Evans was a couple of weeks ago when he said—in fact, he stuck by a previous forecast—that any rise in interest rates that may take place over the next 18 months would only be small. That is what the government reckons—only a small rise in interest rates over the next 18 months. Yet the marketplace is already paying four per cent more, effectively, than it was at the beginning of last month for money for the future—in other words, in 18 months or so.

It seems reasonable to ask the government: why is the marketplace for money wrong in showing this blow-out in interest rates over the next 18 months? It shows that they will rise from 5.75 per cent for the 90-day bank bill rate at the beginning of last month to 9.6 per cent for December next year, 9.86 per cent for the following March and 10.06 per cent—worse than 10 per cent—for the following June. This is for the safest money there is around, namely bank bill futures.

What interests me is that the government has at no stage ever provided any evidence to demonstrate that the 90-day bank bill futures market is not the most accurate indicator of future interest rate moves. It certainly compares much more favourably in terms of success rate than the government's budget forecasts or the Treasurer's—and certainly the Prime Minister's—dismal record.

We need from this government, if it is serious in saying that these interest rates are not going up, an unequivocal assurance that interest rates will not rise over the next 18 months by the further three per cent shown by the 90-day bank bill futures market, or does the prospect of a huge rise of another three percentage points involve a redefinition by this government of the word `small?' I would have thought a huge rise in that percentage rate would have clearly indicated a disastrous trend for those people who have to borrow money to make their businesses run or to build their homes.

Yet in the face of these demands, particularly from the Reserve Bank, that there should be some tightening of fiscal policy, that the government should have a tougher budget so that so much policy burden does not rest on having to put interest rates up, it was only a little while ago that the Prime Minister, Paul Keating, in his arrogance described `all the barrackers for lower deficits'—in other words, people like the opposition, Max Walsh and a lot of other commentators as—`the, you know, failed newsletter writers and all the others that are out there still peddling their morbid tales.' In other words, those who do not agree with Paul Keating are out there peddling a morbid tale.He told the journalist at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: I've been around the fiscal game here nearly longer than anyone in the room.

That might be all right when he is harassing journalists as he is wont to do, but the Governor of the Reserve Bank has been around longer than Paul Keating and he is now saying that there has to be a stronger fiscal policy. In an article in the Canberra Times Mr Ian Henderson said that we could not call Mr Fraser:

. . . one of "the people writing this stuff and [who] have been arguing for the lowest deficits and the biggest surpluses for as long as I have known them." Mr Fraser clearly does support the use of counter-cyclical macroeconomic policy—dealing with inflation and unemployment using monetary as well as fiscal policy.

Here we have all the proper advice showing that there should be greater reliance on fiscal policy and less on interest rates which are, as I said, the dull instrument that bangs the ordinary Australian over the head. This government's policy is a disaster.(Time expired)

What about the messages it must send to prospective overseas buyers of this great source of energy? I know the Democrats, the Greens and others will argue with blinkered—

TALK.START.PARA: —Great for atomic bombs.

—What about Chernobyl?
—The far left of the Labor Party and the Democrats say, `What about Chernobyl.' Let me just quote the actual figures—
—Those two should shut up and let you finish.
—I love the interjections, Senator Collins; do not stop them.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! Senator Parer, you might like to direct your comments to the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Currently, Australia has 30 per cent of the recoverable reserves of uranium in the world and we export 10 per cent. Canada has 10 per cent of reserves and exports 40 per cent. They are playing us off a break. There was a rumour around some years ago that they may well be funding the anti-uranium lobby in this country to their advantage. That was the rumour.
—Not even you could believe that.

—I suppose the machinations in the Labor Party would be such that Senator Collins would believe it. It is pretty tame stuff compared with what goes on in the Labor Party. —It is all right for Senator Spindler to offer throw-away lines—whatever they were. I did not understand what he said.
—I am sure you did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this urgency motion, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Government to take the necessary policy action to ensure Australia has sustainable economic and employment growth.

The Australian Democrats will support this urgency motion. However, we feel it would be fairer if the opposition was a joint target of this motion because the government would not have been able to put into effect the policies which have landed us with almost a million unemployed in Australia, unless the opposition had basically supported time and again the Australian government's economic rationalist, deregulationist policies. In fact, in the last sitting, there were no fewer than three dorothy dixers on manufacturing to enable Senator Cook and Senator Schacht to tell us about growth in manufacturing output and growth in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the government has not been able to boast that it has produced jobs due to the fact that it has produced jobless growth. Despite increases in manufacturing production of 13.9 per cent from the trough of the recession in June 1992, manufacturing now employs 200,000 fewer people than five years ago. In the past, manufacturing was a mass employer, employing hundreds of thousands of workers, directly and indirectly. But as a result of the government's manic obsession with internationalising the economy at reckless speed—an obsession shared by the opposition, as I have said—many of these jobs are gone. In an internationalised economy, Australia's labour-intensive industries cannot compete with the low-wage developing countries. Jobs are lost, directly, as imports from those countries displace Australian products and, indirectly, as those countries entice investment away from Australia—off-shore—to create jobs in other countries.

The economic models of the government's advisers—and obviously those of the opposition's—assume that workers losing their jobs in our labour-intensive industries will somehow, and without delay, move to the new, hi-tech service industries which are purportedly to be our future. Unfortunately, the Ballarat workers who lost their jobs when Ford closed its plant did not suddenly become microchip designers in the Canberra computer industry. The sacked workers from Holeproof in Ararat have not all become tourist operators in Cairns. It is hard to see how the 140 people who have just lost their jobs with Tupperware in Ferntree Gully are suddenly going to start small businesses exporting engineering services to the region.

If we are to increase employment, we must innovate, research and educate. Yet Australia ranks third last among OECD countries in business expenditure on R&D. Neither the government nor the coalition is prepared to increase support for venture capital, either by government or by industry. We know that the real growth in expenditure on R&D has virtually been static. In the 1980s, it was 1.25 per cent of GDP and in 1992 it was 1.35 per cent.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the matter of urgency entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to take the necessary policy action to ensure Australia a sustainable economic and employment growth.

The greens are concerned with sustainability, but what does this mean? A lot of people have questioned whether that word has been co-opted to the point that it is useless; an obligatory filler word in any policy-related statement. However, Professor John Young made a good point that sustainability is a good word because there is no such thing as being `somewhat sustainable'. Sustainability is an absolute and could be defined from a biocentric standpoint as `a way of life sustaining the diversity and resilience of life and sustainable into the foreseeable future'.

PARA.TAB: What does that mean in terms of economics and employment? It means an economic system that does not result in the degradation of life, and is one not predicated on growth of resource use, since growing resource use will always ultimately reach physical limits—and in most cases will reach the limits to what an ecosystem can bear before the physical limits are reached. An economically sustainable system must also be predicated on some measure of distributive equity. It is not sustainable for a few to continue to get richer at the expense of the many. That cannot go on forever. So `sustainable economy' must mean a system where wealth is spread around and everyone benefits.

Sustainable economic growth must therefore be very peculiar. It must be, as it was said in the Brundtland report which advocated growth, an entirely different kind of growth. It could be money growth as payment for services, for work done to existing resources. It cannot be growth based on extraction of new resources. Some people, such as Herman Daley, former World Bank economist, advocate steady state economics—and this does not mean no change.

`Sustainable employment growth' is another very peculiar term, one which needs to be examined carefully. We have real problems now with maldistribution of work. Some people are underemployed, some are unemployed, some are overworked, and some overwork is not paid for; it is obligatory, unpaid overtime. In this context, more work makes no sense as a solution if it means more work for those already working long hours, or simply harder work. No-one would want that. It must mean enough work for everyone. Maybe it means a better distribution of work: more for some and less for others. Maybe we should go to a 32-hour week with no overtime. Enough must also mean enough to do whatever is necessary at a rate of pay that is enough to survive on—and we are back at questions of distribution.

In short, it seems to me that the policy being asked for is one where we could do more with less. It seems to me that this motion is a nonsense motion because `sustainable growth' is not a reality in ecological terms. Sustainable employment might be possible, but not linked with sustainable growth. Therefore, because this motion is such a nonsense, the Greens will be abstaining from voting on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose the motion moved by the opposition. I put it to the Senate that if we are talking about the failure of anything, it is the failure of the opposition. It is the failure of the opposition essentially to make it clear what it stands for. We have seen in recent times consideration given to what the Liberal Party is, 50 years after its creation. We are none the wiser other than to say that the Liberal Party in 1994 stands for office. We cannot determine clearly what it is, other than office, that the Liberal Party currently stands for.

PARA.TAB: What we see is a Liberal Party which was left in reasonably good hands at the retirement of Bob Menzies but is now in complete disarray. It is unable to cope with the changes occurring within our society at large. It is unable to manage itself, let alone propose serious management of this society or this economy.

By contrast, we simply have to look at a few basic indicators of where the government is going. One proposition we cannot get over is that in terms of economic growth Australia is growing at 4 1/2 per cent per annum. By international standards, that is way above OECD averages. When we look at a whole range of other indices we see substantial improvement in the economic performance of this country as a whole. If we turn to housing we see quite dramatic improvements in the levels of construction. In retail trade we see consumer confidence and business surveys show confidence and expectations for the future. All these things point to sustained growth in our economy.

What we see is a government that is committed to a whole range of quite substantial policy objectives which, to a large measure, are being met. It is being done within the context of a social justice framework, which means that we are not looking after just a few. We are attempting to look after many and so produce a society which is much fairer, much more balanced and able to offer real and lasting prosperity to the citizens of this country.

What this government is attempting to do is to secure a rate of economic and employment growth that leads to an increase in real incomes and, by doing so, also reduces unemployment. We are seeking to improve the level of domestic savings. The superannuation policies alone of this government point in that direction. We are seeking to continue the process of creating a more innovative manufacturing nation. The economic statistics once again prove that the government is able to deliver.

We are looking at improvement of the international environment for our export industries by creating new international trade arrangements. Again, the work of this government points to success. We are seeking continued structural change in our economy so that we are able to cope with the pressures of the modern world. I contrast that with the conservatives. What are they saying about these matters? They come back with rhetoric, cliches and essentially no policy.

In looking at other matters, in terms of education we are seeking to establish new national vocational education schemes, provide training schemes and an education scheme of a national basis. The recent ALP national conference took steps to further that progress which is being made. We are seeing a much clearer line defined in terms of meeting the needs of the economy and our citizens who work within that economy, particularly in terms of our education priorities.

We are seeking to enhance social justice in our society, particularly Aboriginal land rights and the social justice implications through the ATSIC arrangements and the land funds that will be debated by this Senate hopefully later this week. We are seeking to establish constitutional and government arrangements which allow us to develop a clearer sense of our own identity as a republic and as a society committed to social democratic values.

We have put all of these things in a framework of government which sees stability and real commitment to realisable objectives. As I say, by contrast what do we see from the opposition? Very little. We see an opposition that essentially is divided, leaderless and rudderless. In that context, it is no wonder that the people of Australia continue to support this government in the way that they do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 23 August 1994, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Off the record: Shield laws for journalists' confidential sources: Inquiry into the rights and obligations of the media: First report, together with submissions to the inquiry and transcripts of evidence which were presented to the President on 7 October 1994.
Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is one of a series that will deal with the media in terms of a number of topics, the first of which has been dealt with in this report and which concerns the keeping of confidentiality of sources. The committee is concerned that some journalists have gone to prison because of their conscientious belief that once they have given an undertaking, either implicitly or explicitly, to a source they would then not be entitled to reveal that source. That has come into conflict with the courts and with court-like bodies such as ICAC or the Criminal Justice Commission, which have insisted that the journalist reveal her or his source.

PARA.TAB: What the committee attempted to do, and hopefully has succeeded in doing, is balance the various public interests concerned in this matter so that a fair result is obtained. A public interest was that there be a free flow of information to people in a democratic society. There was a public interest at the same time that a person who stands accused before a court should have all of the evidence that is relevant to her or his guilt before the court. Indeed, in civil matters, in matters such as an action for libel, there is a public interest in seeing that a plaintiff has available to him or her all the evidence that is available.

The committee has suggested that there be a legislative change to give journalists a protection so that they do not have to reveal the source of their information but make that subject to a number of exceptions in respect of which a court will exercise its discretion to require the journalist to either reveal his or her source or do otherwise. The exceptions include things such as a person's guilt or innocence being at issue and there being an importance to know whether or not the information is true and that establishment of the truth requires the source to be known.

The committee found that, if the credibility and accountability of the media were to increase, the public generally would be much more inclined to give the media privileges where it would not be so inclined to do now. To that end, the committee has recommended that the ethical conduct of the media increase. When we say `the media', we do not simply mean journalists; we mean the whole lot of the media, including journalists, editors, subeditors, owners and whoever else would be associated with publication.

A committee is presently set up by a section of the MEAA, which used to be the AJA, to report on new ethics for journalists. That is being chaired by Father Frank Brennan from the Society of Jesuits. It is a recommendation of this committee that, when that report is to hand, journalists adopt a new pattern for their ethical conduct, they adhere to that and at the same time they set up disciplinary measures that enforce these ethical standards.

The committee recommends that bodies like the judiciary committee of the AJA be given a legislative exemption from any action for libel that might otherwise be brought against it for the publication of its findings. In other words, what the committee recommends is that the parliament legislate to enable an effective self-regulation of the media. If that were done, it is the committee's view that people would be much more ready than they presently are to allow a journalist or any other person from the media to maintain the confidence of sources.

The committee advises that more education for journalists be made available, that a greater emphasis be placed in journalism and courses on journalism on ethics and that as many as possible of the people wanting to take on journalism do so through such courses. The committee found that, by and large, journalists are ethical in their conduct but that there have been some unhappy exceptions. It is in that context that something needs to be done.

The committee does not support absolute privilege for journalists because of the risk that people might be found guilty if certain information were not made available in court cases. However, the committee considers that, where privilege exists for journalists not to give evidence in court about their sources, that privilege should apply equally to journalists called to appear before the ever-growing number of bodies that exercise powers that should properly be confined to royal commissions. There has been too great a growth of bodies with royal commission powers set up on a permanent basis.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to support Senator Cooney in presenting the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of its inquiry into the rights and obligations of the media. The report is notable in that it is a unanimous report across party lines.

PARA.TAB: The committee was faced with a conflict of two principles, both of which reflect notable public interests. One is the free flow of information; the other is the need to disclose the source of information published, particularly where that is essential during the conduct of a court case. In assessing these conflicting principles, the committee arrived at a recommendation which strikes a proper balance. On the one hand, we believe in protection for journalists who on ethical grounds feel that they should not disclose a source of information they have published. On the other hand, we believe that there are and will be many situations where the disclosure of a source is essential.

Among the recommendations, we have listed a range of criteria which the court—it is for the court to decide—should take into account when making a decision about whether disclosure should be made. Perhaps foremost among those criteria is where the disclosure of a source is essential to establishing the truth of the matters published and where that in turn could materially contribute to the outcome of the court case in progress.

I do not propose to canvass all the details that Senator Cooney, as chairman of the committee, has already raised. I thank him for chairing this committee so ably and for eliciting information with such sensitivity—information relevant not only to this report and the many other references that have come before the committee but also to the great issues with which we as a society must grapple, such as the cost of justice, which is presently before the Senate.
