TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 which was introduced into the chamber on 30 August. I remind the Senate that this is the third omnibus tax bill to be before us this year. I understand we will be debating two more before the Senate rises prior to Christmas.

PARA.TAB: This bill, as usual, covers a large range of unrelated income tax measures and also sales tax measures, most of which have a minimal impact on revenue. The exception is the implementation of the reportable payments system which will add $400 million in revenue to the government coffers over the next four years. In fact, the bill was subject to a public hearing on Monday, 19 September by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. The committee heard evidence concerning the provisional tax uplift factor, the dependent spouse rebate and sales tax on re-manufactured goods sold or leased to exempt users, and also received submissions on a number of other issues. Unfortunately, time did not permit consideration of a number of other matters which were of interest to certain committee members.

The bill is not opposed but there are a number of measures which leave a bitter aftertaste in the mouth of each and every coalition member. Not the least of these is maintaining the provisional uplift factor at eight per cent. In addition, the bill seeks to make changes to the CFC regime which is already becoming quite unmanageable and having a detrimental effect on Australian entities investing abroad.

Given the tight time restraints in this place, I only have time to assess a select few elements of the bill. I refer first to regional headquarters. These measures, announced in the white paper on employment and growth in May, provide two types of incentives—income tax and sales tax—to attract regional headquarters of multinationals to our shores.

The decision to provide some relief to regional headquarters comes after years of lobbying, particularly from the finance, accounting and legal sectors, and the measures are welcomed. Unfortunately, they are but a small step in the right direction needed to entice multinationals to use Australia instead of the traditional regional areas of Singapore and Hong Kong for companies operating in Asia.

Surprisingly, the government announced two proposals this year which could actually deter multinationals from setting up regional headquarters here. The first—the draft overseas super funds bill which was released in June this year—proposed that multinationals employing expatriates retaining membership of home country superannuation funds would pay fringe benefits tax on contributions to the fund. It has been suggested that this meant that companies could pay up to three times what was originally intended to go to staff in super. That reference was by Helen Cudlipp from Coopers and Lybrand and appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 27 July 1994.

The second proposal is the changes in the budget threatening to put high capital gains tax and FBT on the typical employee share schemes operated by overseas companies, particularly American companies. On top of that, the ATO is seeking to apply fringe benefits tax to parts of salary packages such as housing allowances and return-home travel received by expatriates working in Australian regional headquarters.

These measures will only act to disenfranchise multinationals. Our tax regime is already not competitive with Asian centres such as Singapore which taxes approved Singapore operation headquarters at only 10 per cent of the fees, royalties and interest it earns in providing management, technical, financial and other supporting services to affiliates outside Singapore. As well, the headquarters is exempt from tax on foreign dividend income.

I remind the Senate that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, pointed out that the Allen Consulting Group report launched on 1 July 1994 found that about 1,100 jobs and economic activity of $350 million a year are generated by the 65 multinationals having regional headquarters in Australia. Obviously, the state governments do not think that the federal government is doing enough. The Kennett government has lured some multinationals with its own incentives, including payroll and land tax concessions, and help on infrastructure development. Queensland has also taken its own initiative and introduced legislation to grant concessions and exemptions in relation to debits tax, land tax, payroll tax and stamp duty for regional headquarters situated in Queensland. We commend them for that.

Despite all the advantages Australia has to offer, there are many reasons why Australia will have difficulty attracting regional headquarters. Lack of capital gains tax relief is likely to be a major impediment, closely followed by its nasty brother, the fringe benefits tax. Foreign business people looking at our FBT rules may be frightened by the complexity and cost of those laws and the new employee share option rules. There are also other problems: the uncertainty as to how much income the Australian regional headquarters should make, given that the transfer pricing provisions will presumably apply to the regional headquarters; and last but not least, that regional headquarters believe that their overseas income could be subject to ordinary Australian income tax.

As to eligible investment funds of registered organisations, I am pleased that the government has indicated that it will be withdrawing the provisions in the bill relating to the eligible investment funds of friendly societies to enable discussions to take place. My hope is that the government will listen with open ears to the very real concerns that those organisations had with the proposed legislation. I think it is somewhat reprehensible that the very important role undertaken by friendly societies over so many years in this country has been changed and that the types of products they will be offering their members will be taxed at such a rate that their lower income earner constituency will inevitably change. I ask the government to give special recognition to the tax impact it intends imposing on friendly societies in terms of the services that they render to their constituency, as the individuals generally have a taxable income very much below the tax rates that we are talking about.

As to the dividend withholding tax exemption, which forms part of the regional headquarters package, this is not limited to shareholders of companies performing regional headquarters activities in Australia. It will also be available to non-resident shareholders of all Australian resident companies which derive qualifying foreign source dividend income.

However—and here is the rub—Australian resident companies in a less than 100 per cent owned group will not benefit from the arrangement. How could we do such a thing? A number of major foreign shareholders in Australian publicly listed companies utilise Australian holding companies to hold those investments.

However, as a result of the definition of a related corporation for foreign dividend account purposes, a dividend paid by the Australian listed company out of its foreign income to the Australian holding company of its major non-resident shareholder cannot be paid out of the foreign dividend account and thus on-paid in turn free of dividend withholding tax to the non-resident shareholder.

What about foreign bank branches? The amendments relating to the taxation of Australian branches of foreign banks are aimed at creating a more equitable tax regime for foreign bank branches operating in Australia. I note that Roger Hogan in an article in the Australian Financial Review on 4 July commented that foreign bankers are questioning how adequately the provisions reflect the realities of the marketplace, and how far they will help the government achieve its aim of making Australia a more competitive financial environment. The rhetoric does not match the legislation.

With regard to sales tax on parts in re-manufactured goods, the bill implements a number of sales tax measures, including allowing a credit for parts, fittings and accessories used in the repair, renovation or upgrading of goods to be exported, provided the tax is not passed on in the price of the alterations. What it fails to do is exempt from sales tax parts used in the re-manufacture of goods by Australian corporations which are subsequently sold or leased to always exempt users, including government departments, exempt government agencies and other exempt non-profit organisations such as schools and hospitals.

This treatment is simply inconsistent with the sales tax treatment of new goods and imported re-manufactured goods sold or leased to the same people. This is an extraordinary situation. One can import goods, sell them to exempt users and get the sales tax provision, but re-manufactured Australian goods that are sold to the same person do not get the sales tax provision applied.

In the committee stage I will put forward an amendment to exempt from sales tax parts used in the re-manufacture of goods for sale or lease to exempt users. Prior to the streamlined sales tax regime which commenced on 1 January 1993, spare parts used in repairs were treated as exempt from sales tax when the repaired goods were sold or leased in exempt circumstances, including sales and leases by always exempt users.

However, under the streamlined sales tax regime, parts used in repair are normally treated as taxable. In December last year, amendments introduced in this chamber allowed the recovery of the sales tax paid on parts used in the repair of goods where those goods were subsequently sold into the mining, agriculture or manufacturing industries for use as an exempt business input. This bill provides a similar credit in respect of spare parts used in goods re-manufactured or repaired and subsequently exported, to reinstate the pre-1 January 1993 status quo.

The amendments I will move in the committee stage will do the same thing for parts used in the re-manufacture of goods for sale or lease to exempt users, in terms of the work done here in Australia by Australian people for always exempt users. It was a promise given that there would not be any new taxation as a result of this change to streamline sales tax. This is a broken promise—and therefore we have a justification for moving an amendment in relation to this item.

An investigation of this item has raised another anomalous situation. I think it is opportune to bring it to the Senate's attention. I am talking about the sales tax exemption for farm equipment; it is only for cash. There is a major problem. Not everybody has the facility of being able to pay cash. A lot of people today lease farm equipment.

While on this topic of streamlined sales tax, I want to indicate this other matter. When the government sought to provide relief last year, it did so through a credit arrangement for parts applied to own use in repairing farm machinery such as harvesters when that refurbished farm equipment was ultimately sold to farmers quoting sales tax certificates. Unfortunately, the relief given was discriminatory since it applied only where a farmer acquires farm machinery not for cash, but under a lease. It seems anomalous that, in these difficult times, farmers face a financial penalty or even a denial of equipment if, owing to financial constraints or other valid reasons, they cannot or do not want to purchase for cash. I call upon the government to give this matter serious consideration.

What about the Royal Flying Doctor Service? There are problems with that. The bill contains an amendment to reinstate the exemption for persons who use wireless transceivers to make contact with radio services conducted by the Royal Australian Flying Doctor Service and similar bodies. Do honourable senators remember the ABC advertising at the weekend, raising money for the flying doctor service? I commend the ABC and the flying doctor service for their initiative and coordination.

I wish to draw to the Senate's attention a third problem with the sales tax legislation, one which is not addressed by this bill. Prior to streamlined sales tax, there was an exemption for wireless transceivers `for use'—they are the operative words—in conjunction with the radio service conducted by the RFDS and other similar services. The term `for use' was accepted as meaning an appreciable or significant use of the goods.

The current sales tax legislation exempts wireless transceivers for use by an authorised person `mainly' in conjunction with radio services for the RFDS and others. I have received a representation that the inclusion of the word `mainly' in the legislation has effectively removed the exemption for most people authorised to use wireless transceivers, because it is extremely difficult to satisfy the `for use mainly' test. `Mainly' is defined as meaning `to the extent of more than 50 per cent'. The explanatory memorandum of the Sales Tax (Classifications and Exemptions) Bill 1992, which implements the streamlined sales tax regime, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there will be no significant change in the coverage of the exemption.
However, it continued to say:

. . . wireless transceivers could satisfy that test and still be used mainly for another purpose. To more clearly focus the exemption, it will now apply to wireless transceivers for use mainly with those services.
One must assume that the significant change to the test was unintended if this is the only reason given for the change in wording.

PARA.TAB: There are many users of wireless transceivers in remote areas, including travellers in remote areas, mining company employees, residents in remote localities and transport industry workers. Naturally, those users would also utilise their transceivers for personal and private communications. Despite the improvement in telephone communications, most homesteads in remote Australia still retain HF receivers for emergency use and to talk to workers on their property. This is the only contact these workers can have for emergency purposes with the RFDS.

Notwithstanding this, under the current legislation all these users purchasing radio transceivers will not receive the sales tax exemption unless they buy the receiver mainly for emergency situations. This will thwart the purpose and use of transceivers, which are invaluable in the event of emergency. Transceivers are an essential safety measure in outback Australia. Tragic accidents could have been avoided if victims had had HF transceivers. The government should be using exemptions, such as exemptions from sales tax, to encourage users to purchase receivers—instead of worrying about a few dollars of sales tax revenue it would have to forgo.

Having said that, I would like to point out to the government that the Adelaide branch of the ATO has given interim approval to one manufacturer of transceivers to classify radio transceivers on the basis of the exemption under the old sales tax legislation. Here again we have a favourable, good decision from Adelaide; but it is inconsistent with the act. I call upon the government to clarify the position.

In conclusion, I call on the government to take close note of the comments I have made in relation to just a few of the many difficulties arising from this legislation before us today. The bill clearly illustrates the dangers involved in the simplification of legislation. Time and time again in this chamber we have heard that provisions of the streamlined sales tax legislation do not reflect the tenor of its predecessor. This should give the government an idea of the dangers which the new taxation substantiation bill faces. Business has waited years for that legislation. I certainly hope it measures up to the high expectations the government has created.

I must say that there have been some good recommendations, in terms of the first attempt. But I do not believe they go far enough because, if the underlying philosophy is under question, plain English will not overcome that difficulty. We will perhaps address those issues in greater detail in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which will be around shortly. The article by Michael Dwyer recently in the Australian Financial Review suggested that taxpayers and practitioners, under the possibility of needing substantiation, will have to examine the old and the new acts to work out their obligations. This is not the consequence that business had hoped for.

Before I finish, I would like to foreshadow an amendment in relation to the home child-care allowance, an amendment that will be moved in the committee stage by my colleague Senator Patterson. That issue was subject to debate. We note the government will be putting an amendment in order to honour its commitments, so that people will not be worse off under the new arrangements and will have the facility, as from the end of September, to use the new allowance—paid under Social Security—or continue the income tax measure in the form of a rebate.

For people moving to the child-care allowance under Social Security, I remind them that they need to see their paymaster because new declaration forms will have to be lodged. Failure to lodge will mean that the pay will be taken out at a rate of tax which is not consistent with what ultimately they will be assessed upon. They could well be up for $1,000 or more in tax as a result of these changes. I suggest they consult their paymasters immediately.

People will have to do some sums to see whether they will be worse off in terms of the new allowances under Social Security than they were under the income tax rebate scheme. I foreshadow an amendment to be moved by my colleague Senator Patterson. Her concerns are that this measure would be best addressed using Social Security arrangements. Senator Patterson will be addressing those issues not only during the second reading debate but also during the committee stage, when she will be putting her amendment. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is another omnibus bill which proposes to make a variety of changes to Australia's taxation law. It covers measures announced in the last two budgets and in the government's employment white paper which was handed down in May of this year. My colleague Senator Watson has the main carriage of this bill for the opposition, particularly so far as the technical aspects of it are concerned, along with my other colleague Senator Patterson. I do not propose to go into much, if any, detail of the specific measures. I will leave that to Senator Watson and Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: There are some things I want to say about the bill and the context in which it was introduced, both of a specific and a general nature. The bill covers a number of sales tax amendments, including measures which were first uncovered as problems during the 1992 Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation. That legislation—I note that Senator McMullan is here at the moment; I think he was one of those who were loudest in hailing that exercise as one of major simplification—turned out to raise more areas of concern and confusion with respect to wholesale sales tax than was the situation in the old law. Far from it turning out to be a simplification exercise, as the opposition told the government it would be at the time, it proved to be even more complicated than in the past and even more confusing and costly to the clients of the tax department, particularly so far as small businesses were concerned.

Yet the government at the time, with the support of the Australian Democrats, in a desperate hurry to rush through that flawed wholesale sales tax overhaul before the 1993 election, ignored a number of very serious issues which were raised in the submissions presented to the Senate committee and in the evidence given at hearings of that committee. I recall that Senator Watson and I, who were very active in that committee, along with those people who agreed with us, knew that the government was causing more problems than it was seeking to solve. I note that, two years later, the government is proposing some amendments which should have been incorporated into the legislation before it became law, but I do not believe it has gone far enough even now.

The bill also contains amendments to another of Labor's hotchpotch pieces of major taxation law; namely, that of foreign source income. The government's taxation treatment of what are known as FIFs has been identified as one of the most complex and onerous burdens in Australian taxation history. These further necessary amendments that the government is now proposing seek only to illustrate the flaws in the current regime.

Other measures in this bill are the relatively limited provisions of taxation relief for regional headquarters as announced in the so-called Working Nation statement; consequential changes required to implement the home child-care allowance and partner allowance, about which Senator Patterson will go into in some detail; and foreign branch banking proposals first announced in June 1993.

The other major item in the bill—it is a controversial one—is the reduction in the uplift factor for provisional tax from 10 per cent to only eight per cent—a relatively small reduction. That is being done at a time when inflation is being forecast by the government to be something like 2 1/4 per cent and there is an average earnings growth of about 3.5 per cent. So there is certainly a major discrepancy between the uplift factor and inflation. Even if we were to take into account the average earnings growth and add it in, we would see that there is still a very major discrepancy between inflation and earnings growth on the one hand and the uplift factor on the other.

By reducing the uplift factor further below the limited reduction to eight per cent, the government would not lose revenue in the longer run but would delay and reduce its collection this year and therefore put more money in the hands of business and less in the hands of government. At a time when capital expenditure is important for small business, this tax slug, which takes cash out of firms' hands and puts it into the government's pocket for 12 months, will only hinder the opportunities for small businesses to expand.

The eight per cent uplift factor is yet another government induced cost burden on small business and on retired and self-employed people—the very people over whom the government, as I said in a debate earlier today, sheds crocodile tears. But when it comes to the actual actions of government it does nothing but cause them more and more hardship. It is unfair, I believe, in the current low inflation and low earnings environment.

This is a budget measure, and that is something that the coalition takes into account in its consideration of its attitude towards the bill. Nevertheless, it is a matter of the strongest condemnation and criticism of the government that it should be attacking small business in this way at this time against the advice of most people, including members of the opposition.

This measure, amongst others in the bill, shows the Keating Labor government's complete lack of commitment and/or understanding to making Australian industry world competitive. That surely is what we all ought to be about. If we want to raise our living standards here in Australia, if we want to improve our quality of life, we have to make Australia increasingly an internationally competitive country. That means doing things which assist businesses, both small and large, rather than inhibit and retard them in the way this government does.

In that context, I refer the Senate to the recent World Economic Forum's competitiveness index, which shows Australia lagging at number 15. That is despite our nation's immense natural resources, our stable political system, our high levels of education and qualifications and our geographical position on the edge of the world's fastest growing and largest regional market. Top of the list in the World Economic Forum's competitive index, the title of the most competitive nation, is the United States—a nation regularly derided by this Labor government, particularly during the years of republican administration, an administration which has returned America to a position as a world leader; a nation which, notwithstanding its own problems, has a much lower level of debt as a proportion of GDP and also a much lower level of unemployment than we have; and a nation which has arguably the world's highest living standards despite the problems that it, along with other nations, faces.

To highlight the starkness of the contrast between the United States' position and ours, in 1992—the last year for which I have comparable figures—the United States net foreign debt ratio as a proportion of GDP was 9.3 per cent. Australia's figure was no less than 39 per cent. In other words, our foreign debt as a proportion of our total annual income was four times greater than that of the United States. That puts an enormous millstone around the neck of the Australian economy, the neck of Australian business and the neck of Australian exporters.

On this competitiveness index, second, third and fourth are three of our Asian neighbours—Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong, respectively. Setting aside Japan, which is a fully-fledged developed country, the other two have always been regarded by Australia as developing countries and not in the same league as we are. How things change! After 11 years of Labor government in this country, those two nations—Singapore and Hong Kong—have now surpassed Australian living standards and look set to continue to leave Australia further behind as they continue their high growth rate.

It is also interesting to note that those two nations have taken distinctly different paths to prosperity: Singapore has taken a far more authoritarian approach to government policy than Hong Kong, or even Australia in some respects; Hong Kong has flourished as the closest thing to a laissez faire system that the world presently has. If we are not just going to keep up but to surpass other countries in competitive growth we have to find our own way of doing it and not just ape other countries.

Earlier today, as a matter of urgency, on behalf of the coalition I initiated a debate on the failure of the government to follow its policy and take the sort of action that will result in sustained employment and economic growth. It is incredible that this government and, in particular, the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, have been so arrogantly complacent about the problems facing our nation, saying that there is not much more that this government needs to do to put in place the reforms that are necessary if we are to get sustainable long term growth. As a nation, we cannot afford to sit idly by while the rest of the world streaks on past us.

Some of our key economic statistics point to the fact that we are dropping back in the competitiveness race. Our basic economic statistics show that we have continuing mass unemployment—still almost 10 per cent as compared with 3 per cent for Hong Kong and Singapore, 6 per cent for the United States and 8 per cent or so for New Zealand. There are many other countries which are also much lower.

We have the largest, most rapidly growing current account deficit of any country in the western world. It is already over 4 per cent of our annual national income. That is certain to be significantly exceeded in the course of this year judging by the figures we saw last month of a $2.1 billion current account deficit—the third largest in our history despite the fact that we are still in the relatively early stages of economic recovery.

As a result of government policy the cost of capital is enormously high. If we look at the 10-year bond rate, we see that real interest rates are now more than 10 per cent while in Japan they are 4 per cent, in New Zealand they are 6 per cent, in the United States they are 4 1/2 per cent and in the United Kingdom they are 6 to 6 1/2 per cent. In other words, we are putting an added burden on our industry and individual borrowers by these relatively high real interest rates—certainly high by comparison with other countries and even by comparison with our historical standards. Indeed, in the western world, only Sweden and Canada—for both of which there are some exceptional explanatory circumstances—have higher real interest rates than Australia.

We also have the continuing problem of low investment. Private fixed capital expenditure in Australia is still at a near low record level. Even if the government attains the growth in capital expenditure of 14 1/2 per cent that it forecast for this year, that still will not bring us up to the average level of the past. If we do not have a high level of investment we will not get the job creation and economic growth that is absolutely essential.

Linked inexorably to that is the level of national savings. We still have near record low levels of national savings. As the ANZ research department recently said, it is only in the last two quarters that as a nation we have had any positive savings at all. We had a run of eight quarters or more where we lost savings each quarter rather than gained them.

All those matters should be of very considerable concern. They point out very starkly that if we continue the way we are going there is no way in the world that the present level of acknowledged economic growth—we do not deny today's report that we are near a five-year high in economic growth—can be sustained if we do not put in place the necessary, underpinning changes and reforms. If we were not seeing the sort of economic growth we are having at the moment we should be very worried because we are in the process of coming out of one of the most protracted recessions on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —And going into the next one.

—Of course our economic growth would be healthy looking; the critical thing is whether it can continue. As Senator Patterson says, we will head for another boom-bust if we do not make the necessary changes to enable us to become internationally competitive on an ongoing basis.

PARA.TAB: There are many things that can and should be done. This is not a situation outside our control. The coalition has regularly pointed out such things. We detailed them in a broad, directional sense in the statement titled The Things That Matter. That document goes into some detail on the range of initiatives and goals that can be achieved.

We can boost business investment in Australia by reducing the complexity and burden of things like the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and other business oncosts by reducing government regulation and red tape. We can improve productivity by empowering employees and employers to negotiate employment agreements directly, by encouraging employees to have a stake in their work force, and by achieving higher real wages through linking them with higher productivity. We can give flexibility to award and enterprise agreements.

We can increase national savings by giving incentives to save and by running a responsible fiscal policy rather than the reckless, huge deficit policy that this government has pursued for many years now. We can increase national savings by reducing public debt, by privatising many government corporations, and by increasing the flexibility of superannuation operations and options. We can create jobs by ensuring that we have a vibrant and competitive small business sector and by revitalising the processes of economic reform which create secure, long-term employment in internationally competitive firms.

There are many things we can do and our tax system is an important part of that. It is quite clear from this taxation amendment bill, which is indicative and symptomatic of all its other policies, that this government does not have a clue about what is necessary to get the economy going on a sustained and sustainable basis. That is the great tragedy that we face as a nation. That is why we continue to express our concerns about the direction of the government's economic policy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 makes a series of amendments to the taxation legislation in Australia and includes measures which give effect to announcements in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 budgets and the Working Nation white paper delivered on 4 May 1994. I could give a speech on the title of that document—Working Nation. It is a misnomer.

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes an extensive list of alterations to income tax legislation relating to reportable payments, foreign investment funds, income tax concessions for regional headquarters, social security payments, provisional tax, deductions for bequests and gifts, superannuation and to a variety of sales tax provisions. I wish to speak on one aspect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), namely, the consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 required as a result of the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

The amendments to the act are necessary to complement the payment of the new home child-care allowance for couples with dependent children. The amendments will remove a taxpayer's entitlement to the dependent spouse rebate where the taxpayer's spouse qualifies for the home child-care allowance. The amendments also exempt home child-care allowance payments from income tax.

The amendments as proposed in this section of the bill as drafted would have meant that, where the spouse of a taxpayer qualifies for the home child-care allowance, the taxpayer would not be entitled to claim the dependent spouse rebate through the tax system. The government has obviously become increasingly aware of the very considerable disquiet surrounding the way in which the home child-care allowance is being implemented, and particularly the sleight of hand involved.

The very fact that the government has indicated that it will move an amendment to provide that families are able to fall back on the without-child dependent spouse rebate if they qualify for that rebate is a good indication that the government has realised that the legislation was fundamentally flawed. The bill is another example of so much of this government's legislation—particularly legislation which deals with the family.

Each time the government introduces a new proposal it is announced with a great deal of `politically correct' rhetoric and public relations hype which is intended to disguise the reality. Inevitably it turns out to be little more than a clever sleight of hand. In the end, there is little improvement for the majority of families, and there is a serious deterioration in the situation of many, despite Mr Keating's constant claims, in this case, that no family would be worse off.

We should remember the parenting allowance and the splitting of the newstart and jobstart allowances. The parenting allowance was announced in the white paper amid vocal claims by the Prime Minister about supporting the family. It was proclaimed as a parenting allowance of up to $132.65 per week for families in which only one parent is employed. In reality, it applied to only about 118,000 Australian families and most of those were going to receive far less than $132.65 a week.

On the day of the election the Prime Minister said that a person staying at home caring for a child would get $30. There was also incredible hype surrounding the announcement that jobstart and newstart would be split between an unemployed married couple. There was to be no more money; in fact, it was to be the same amount of money and it was paid to two people instead of one. We heard a lot of rhetoric about the government doing great things for families.

The legislation to introduce the home child-care allowance was no different. When the Senate debated the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partners Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, I described it as a pea and thimble sleight of hand where the government took with one hand and gave with the other. Before the last election the government deliberately gave the impression that women at home would get an extra $30 a week.

After Mr Keating appeared on television that day I can remember somebody saying to me, `Where are they going to get the money from?' It is clear that the government was going to get the money from the dependent spouse rebate. However, many people did not realise that until they found that they were not getting it in their tax. People thought they were going to get both allowances, but they were hoodwinked. In fact, those people were going to get a mere $2.60—the price of a loaf of bread and a litre of milk. That is not what Mr Keating said when he made the announcement during the election campaign.

This situation was exactly like that of the Christmas appeal. The government said, `We will match dollar for dollar in the Christmas appeal'. What happened when the charities went along? It was dollar for dollar raised and spent during Christmas time, not dollar for dollar raised. Every time Mr Keating makes an announcement there is a trick involved. Hopefully, Australians have woken up that every time Mr Keating opens his mouth with a promise they can bet their bottom dollar—well, the last dollar they have—that he will take that dollar and give it back somewhere else. In other words, people will not be receiving a new dollar.

How many of those families who heard the promise made by the Prime Minister that a person at home was going to get $30 a week ever understood that the dependent spouse rebate was going to be taken away? Very few, if any. The Prime Minister said that no family would be worse off under the home child-care allowance. It was almost as good as Mr Hawke's promise that no child would live in poverty. Mr Keating's promise was a great big distortion of the truth, if I am allowed to say that. I will not use the word `lie', but he was distorting the truth or skating on the circumference of the truth. Thousands of families were going to be worse off. Once again, the government gave with one hand and took with the other and tricked people into thinking that they were going to get $30 extra.

Let me make it clear that, when the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill was debated, the coalition acknowledged that a number of real benefits would be derived from transferring families with dependent spouses and children from the dependent spouse rebate to the home child-care allowance. These benefits included the home child-care allowance being paid directly to the parent caring for the child or children; this was a step in the direction of recognising the contribution of those people caring for children at home.

The coalition also acknowledged that the home child-care allowance was being paid at a slightly higher maximum rate of $60 per fortnight. We also acknowledged that families whose tax liability was too low to receive the full benefit of the dependent spouse rebate were eligible for the home child-care allowance. We also acknowledged that parents leaving the paid work force to care for a dependent child would perhaps be able to claim the home child-care allowance, even though their income for that financial year might exceed the dependent spouse rebate income threshold.

But the coalition pointed out some very serious problems with the home child-care allowance. Many of these concerns remain and, together with the confusion evident in the community, were highlighted in evidence given to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

I will list some of the injustices in this legislation. There was no mention in the Labor Party policy document that families with students in full-time education would be excluded; that families who were temporarily overseas would be excluded; that families with students receiving Austudy would be excluded; or that families would be excluded as a result of the more onerous Social Security income definitions.

I will give the Senate an example of some families overseas. As chairman of a large academic department, I know for a fact that when many young academics go on study leave they do so at considerable personal expense. They uproot their families, they go to another country, and they are being paid within the income tax system within Australia. They have to try to rent their homes and they have to have accommodation overseas. They receive no extra income. Many of these people go overseas with no scholarships—I know; I have done it myself, and I know how costly it is. They have to pay for airfares.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available to me tonight I would like to pay a respectful tribute to a man who was the former head of the Prime Minister's department for many years and who was, in my view, one of Australia's greatest public servants, Sir Geoffrey John Yeend, who died last Thursday on 6 October aged 67, having been born on 1 May 1927. Sir Geoffrey—or as most people knew him, Geoff Yeend—really was a tremendous public servant and a wonderful person. I cannot claim to have been a close friend of Geoff Yeend, but I did know him personally and well over many years. Therefore, I would like to pay this tribute to him.

PARA.TAB: He is the second major public service figure to have died recently—the most recent one, of course, was Sir Frederick Wheeler, who died at the age of 80 just a couple of months ago. In many ways they were both of the same school and of a similar mould because they believed totally in the integrity and impartiality of public service and in the essential value of the due process of administration as the only way to lead to ongoing impartial and correct policy making decisions.

In my remarks tonight I shall draw very heavily on some of the comments that have been made in obituaries in recent days, particularly by John Farquharson in the Canberra Times and by Stuart Hamilton in the Australian. As far as Geoff Yeend's career was concerned, his whole life was spent in public service. He started in the Commonwealth Public Service in 1945, or thereabouts, when he joined the then very powerful Department of Post-War Reconstruction. He joined that department after having spent a couple of years towards the end of the war in the 2nd AIF.

He spent four years in the Department of Post-War Reconstruction before joining the Department of Prime Minister in 1950, where he was the personal assistant to the then head of the Prime Minister's department, Sir Allen Brown. After a couple of years he went across to the Old Parliament House, where he was the principal private secretary to the then Prime Minister, Mr Robert Menzies, from 1952 to 1955. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that he became principal private secretary to Robert Menzies at the age of 25, which is something worth noting.

After that he went to London, where he was an assistant secretary to the Australian High Commission between 1958 and 1960, having gone back to the Prime Minister's department after his stint with Menzies. In 1961 he was appointed an assistant secretary to the Prime Minister's department and six years later a first assistant secretary. In 1971 he won a Churchill fellowship and went abroad for about six months on that fellowship, something that he always very highly regarded. When he came back in 1972 he was appointed deputy secretary to the Department of Prime Minister. In 1977, or thereabouts, he was appointed by the then Prime Minister Fraser as head of the department following the death of Sir Alan Carmody.

He had the wonderful knack of being able to serve governments and leaders of all political persuasions with equal impartiality. He worked through governments ranging from the Curtin years through to the Hawke years. He retired due to ill health in 1986 whilst head of the department under Prime Minister Hawke. Stuart Hamilton, who worked with him for many years, in his article in the Australian stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Many qualities stood out for those fortunate to work with Yeend: his calmness at times of crisis . . . his essential decency and integrity; his capacity to distil the essence of a complex argument or tortuous negotiation in a short well-crafted piece of advice, with a cunningly placed sting or sweetener that would entice the recipient; his great kindness to staff at times of private stress; and his capacity to attract and act as a mentor to staff from around the service—no fewer than 13 officers who worked for him as secretary at some point in their career went on to become secretaries of Commonwealth departments.

PARA.TAB: He took a deep interest in Public Service renewal and reform throughout his career . . . His interests were not limited to his career, nor was his commitment to service. He had longstanding involvement with hockey at the local, national and international levels . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He worked with many service organisations as diverse as the Multiple Sclerosis Society, the National Gallery Foundation, the Australia-Japan Foundation, the Australian Volleyball Association, the National Eisteddfod and the Menzies Memorial Trust.

PARA.TAB: On his death last week many people have paid tribute to him. The Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, very rightly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: "Sir Geoffrey will be remembered as much for the many things he achieved as for the person he was: wise, kind and generous . . .
"He was an outstanding Australian who excelled in his many fields of endeavour and whose qualities of integrity, loyalty and service made him so respected and admired throughout the community."
The former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, who, as I said, appointed Sir Geoffrey as head of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in the late 1970s, described him as follows:
. . . "one of Australia's best public servants in the traditional sense, something we have probably lost for all time because of the politicisation of the Public Service.

PARA.TAB: "Any government would have had total faith in Sir Geoffrey . . .

SPEECH.PARA: To those of us who had the privilege of knowing him at some stage and in some way during his long and illustrious career, I think we would certainly say `Amen' to that. To finish on a lighter note, it was of Sir Geoffrey that the famous story, which apparently is true, has come through the folklore of recent years. In 1982, when the then Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser was hospitalised, Sir Geoffrey, as his permanent head, and Doug Anthony, who was the acting Prime Minister, went to see Malcolm Fraser in hospital. While they were there the program Yes, Minister was playing on television. They all stopped and had a look at this segment of Yes, Minister. Walking out after having seen Malcolm Fraser, Doug Anthony and Geoff Yeend said one to the other, `Did you notice that we all laughed but at different spots?'

PARA.TAB: That in many ways epitomises a great deal about Geoff Yeend. He was a person who lived with politics. In many ways he was above politics. In many ways he was a very skilled bureaucratic politician, getting the best out of everyone in the governments for which he worked in such an impartial way. He will be very sadly missed by all of those who knew him. To his widow Laurel and his family, I extend my deepest sympathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some regret tonight to speak on a matter which concerns people in Queensland and to criticise people in the Queensland government whom I have known for many years. I believe that small people in Queensland have been treated with great injustice in a number of instances, and I do not believe that a government should hide behind its ability to cover up embarrassing actions by its agents.

PARA.TAB: On Wednesday, 31 August, Senator Jocelyn Newman, chair of the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, tabled her committee's unanimous all-party report in the Senate. One recommendation in the report called on `the Queensland government to establish an independent investigation into certain unresolved whistleblower cases within its jurisdiction.' One such case was the Lindeberg case. On the same day, Queensland senators Warwick Parer and Cheryl Kernot placed on the public record certain facts which showed that a prima facie conspiracy to attempt to obstruct justice had occurred.

The Courier-Mail of 1 September 1994 covered Senator Parer's speech in the Senate which brought the issue alive on the floor of parliament in Queensland. That evening the 7.30 Report featured Kevin Lindeberg's four-year struggle to expose the illegal shredding and its cover-up. The debate in the Queensland parliament led to the tabling by Minister Warner on 2 September 1994 of a crucial letter from the office of cabinet to the state archivist dated 23 February 1990 which set out the reason why cabinet sought the archivist's urgent approval to destroy these public records.

That crucial letter had been sought by Lindeberg since January 1993 under an FOI application. The letter had been held by the information commissioner for over 10 months. Key passages had been withheld. The information commissioner had been fully informed by evidence that the Heiner material was central to and required in known anticipated litigation, and that the `cabinet exempt' passages in the letter of 23 February 1990 were of pivotal importance in establishing the offence.

Cabinet's decision outlined in the letter of 23 February 1990 sought the destruction of the material because `it was no longer required or pertinent to the public record'. That was demonstrably false. Its contents proved one crucial element in establishing the conspiracy to obstruct justice. The only element left unresolved was who conclusively knew about Mr Coyne's anticipated litigation in which that evidence was central to those foreshadowed court proceedings. That answer was also resolved in documentation acknowledged by Minister Warner in parliament on 6 September 1994 and later confirmed in the Courier-Mail on 8 September 1994.

Minister Warner informed parliament on 18 May 1993 that cabinet took the decision to destroy these public records on 5 March 1990 `in order to reduce the risk of legal action against any of the parties involved'. Throughout this period there was plenty of time to double-check with Mr Coyne regarding his intention to commence court proceedings.

One crucial question in this conspiracy remains unresolved in pinpointing all the conspirators with full knowledge before the offence. Many questions remain unanswered. Did Minister Warner inform her cabinet colleagues of all the facts on 5 March 1990, including Mr Coyne's legal notice of 15 February 1990, and the support of his litigation by two unions in seeking a court decision concerning access to those public records under public service management and employment regulation 65? Or did she withhold crucial information on the three times it came to cabinet before the shredding was ordered in order to reduce the risk of legal action?

Minister Warner informed parliament that cabinet allegedly acted on the advice of the state archivist and crown solicitor. Evidence now shows that this is not and cannot be true. It is now established that the state archivist was not given all the facts. She was misled by one or more public officials by not being informed of Mr Coyne's statutory demand on the material of 8 February 1990 and foreshadowed court proceedings of 15 February 1990. It is an offence under the Queensland criminal code and Criminal Justice Act of 1989 to cause any public official not to act honestly and impartially. The state archivist could only do that by knowing all the facts when executing her public duties in this matter. Her duty is to protect public records in the public interest. Important facts were withheld from her in order to commit the offence of obstructing justice.

It is contradictory in itself that cabinet sought her urgent approval to destroy public records no longer required or pertinent to the public record. Why the haste over documents of no seeming importance?

The crown solicitor's advice which allegedly advised cabinet to shred public records was dated 16 February 1990. Minister Warner confirmed publicly on 8 September 1994 that she never received Mr Coyne's solicitor's notice until 19 February 1990. How could the crown solicitor's advice support cabinet's decision when it was written on 16 February 1990, three days earlier? The crown solicitor's written advice could not have addressed Mr Coyne's official notification by Minister Warner's own admission because its alleged receipt occurred after the crown solicitor's advice was written.

Many other issues certainly impinge on this matter. It is with no great pleasure that I place these issues on the public record. Much more could be said; particularly the fact that, eventually, Mr Lindeberg lost his position with the trade union and ever since has been castigated and prejudiced in his ability to gain employment. I believe that it needs much further investigation and I would hope that the Senate, if not the Queensland government, would take that kind of action.

In conclusion, because the documents are relevant to the statements that I have made tonight, I seek leave to table a number of letters relevant to this statement. I have given these to various ministers, to Senator Herron and Senator Vanstone.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I agree totally with the sentiments of my colleague Senator Woodley and support his statements, I rise to speak briefly on a very different topic; that is, age as a rationale for health care. It is a disturbing concept that has been raised in the past month in several different arenas. Dr Colin Honey, Director of the Kingswood Centre for Ethics, in some comments which achieved front page headlines in the West Australian last month, gave an impetus to the provocative thesis that is emerging in many Western countries and now in Australia that age should be a limiting factor in decisions to allocate certain kinds of health services to the elderly. This concept serves to debase old age at a time when it should be affirmed.

PARA.TAB: Giving the aged poor their pension and providing them with medical care is at the very least a prerequisite for their self-respect and their dignity, but it is not a sufficient condition. More importantly, it is the manner of the giving that counts and the moral basis on which it is given. Propositions such as using age as a rationale for health care undermine respect and dignity as components of a moral society.

Although there are times when a decision to remove a life support system must be made, we should be disturbed and anxious when our society talks about setting involuntary limits. If age becomes a limiting factor in the provision of medical treatment, apart from the obvious appalling consequences to which many have already taken objection, there is another consequence, presumably unintended, which I wish to emphasise. The limits that will be set according to this rationale will be limits that affect women much more drastically than they affect men because of their longer life expectancy.

I do not wish to suggest that Dr Honey intended to be sexist as well as ageist; however, with age as a criterion for health care, women are put in a most precarious position. Not only are there many more elderly women than men, but also these older women are poorer, more apt to live alone and less likely to have informal social and personal supports than their male counterparts. Furthermore, a disproportionate number of nursing home patients are women. None of the arguments for rationing health care by age takes note of the implications for women of employing such a criterion, nor of the special plight of older women.

None of the arguments about the limits of society's obligations to the aged acknowledges the historical failures of the health care system to note gender differences in medical research, diagnosis and treatment. None of the arguments addresses the question of whether there might be differences in the definition of natural lifespan or one's perception of a tolerable death—a death that occurs when one has accomplished what life has to offer—that are gender relative. None of the arguments takes note of the fact that the limits suggested would have tragic consequences for women. A biographical definition of life fails to take adequate note of the differences in the biographies of men and women. To believe that it is desirable to adopt the use of an age standard suggests that a woman's life should be viewed as completed earlier in her biological chronology than it actually is; that is, when procreation, child rearing, housekeeping and the maintaining of conjugal relationships are complete. One could be forgiven for thinking that when men feel that their lifespan will be over they similarly feel that nobody else will have any importance. The argument in favour of believing that there is an appropriate time in a person's biography for claiming that her life could be considered full could be advancing forms of male bias: both a general devaluation of women's concerns and an indifference to a woman's life possibilities, apart from her use in more servile positions in relation to men.

A biographical definition of life also seems to measure a person's life by the notion of a range of experiences without taking note of any qualitative measure of those experiences. In so far as women have historically been disadvantaged with respect to their achievements, their interests, their economic, social and political status, and their sexuality, many would argue that the quality of their life experiences has been so low that with respect to what counts as a tolerable death such a definition begs the question.

Because of the value attached to providing for another financially, women's responsibility to others continues in large part to be described as consisting in caring work, kin work, consumption work and other forms of so-called invisible work—and, of course, largely unpaid work.
It is easy to imagine someone arguing that a women who is single, or who outlives her spouse or whose children are independent, has also outlived her usefulness and her obligations.

Furthermore, because women live longer than men and have been in the work force a shorter time than men, and hence have less provision for their old age, women could also be perceived as undeservedly requiring more in the way of others' responsibilities towards them. As the largest and poorest population of the elderly, women will have the greatest need for increased social and non-financial forms of support as well as health care. This could be used against them in the evaluation of health resources.

The use of an age criterion for determining how to allocate health care resources seems to manifest society's perception that youth is valuable and advanced age, particularly female age, has less worth. The social implications of this are far too reminiscent of the ideal Aryan race. Again, because of their numbers, women constitute the majority of those affected by abuse and neglect. Attitudes that support these practices can only be reinforced by the belief that there is an age beyond which one is getting more than her fair share.

In conclusion, arguments for rationing on the basis of age seem to rest on the presumption that there is little value in providing certain health services to people who have reached the end of `full and natural lives'. That presumption is not gender neutral nor isolated in the health area, but could equally be applied to the arguments surrounding women's employment conditions, superannuation and pension age. Setting age limits for health services not only debases old age and engenders outrage, despair and sadness but is a frightening indictment of how far new right economics dominates our political climate.

PARA.TAB: (1) The ABC does not keep separate cost or revenue figures relating to corporate video production services. Corporate video production services are part of ABC Facilities Hire which includes hire of facilities as well as full scale production work.
The gross revenue, costs of goods sold and administrative and overheads expenditure leading to net revenue for the ABC Facilities Hire for the last four years is set out in Table I below

(2) ABC Television each year develops a staffing structure to meet core free to air production and transmission activities. Marketing requirements are not taken into account when establishing this staff infrastructure.

(5) The basic guidelines set up at the commencement of the facilities hire business in 1989 are:
the ABC will provide for its own needs and will then hire out the remaining down time;

(6) (a) The ABC is not aware of the complete cost structure of its facilities hire competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports in Defence Marketing International, dated 10 June 1994, that Australia is encouraging United States (US) defence firms to use the country as a base for arms sales to Asia, as part of a drive to attract more high-tech companies to establish bases in Australia:
(1) Will the Minister confirm that this is a current strategy for Australia.

(2) Please detail how the Government will be encouraging US defence firms to operate in Australia and how this strategy fits with our policy of self-reliance, for example, how can Australia be self-reliant if we are relying on US defence firms.

(3) Has the Government undertaken, or does it plan to undertake, a cost-benefit analysis of the economic, social and environmental impact of these firms coming to Australia; if so, what factors are being measured.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) It is general Government policy to encourage overseas companies, whether defence or non-defence related, to establish operations in Australia as a base for exports and other dealings with Asia.

It is also longstanding Defence policy to foster in Australian industry the technologies and industry capabilities required to support Australian Defence Force (ADF) operations in the self-reliant defence of Australia. To realise this policy, Australia relies on a combination of overseas technology and indigenous technology and industry capabilities.

As part of this strategy, foreign defence-related companies participate in our major capital purchases, either by teaming with Australian companies or by establishing their own Australian subsidiaries as an integral part of the Australian industry base.

Defence policy for industry recognises that ADF peacetime materiel requirements may not, of themselves, generate sufficient business to sustain the industry capabilities in Australia that Defence needs. Local defence industry is encouraged to compete for defence business overseas within a framework of defence export controls, as an adjunct to its support for the ADF. In addition, and as outlined in Strategic Review 1993, exports to South-East Asia and the South-West Pacific in particular can serve Australia's objective of regional security.

(3) The Government does consider the implications for our strategic industrial base of the involvement by foreign-owned companies. Foreign-owned defence companies establishing in Australia are, in general, no different in their impact than other foreign investment and are subject to the same government processes. Such enterprises are also subject to the same range of laws and other requirements—economic, social and environmental—that apply generally to the rest of local industry.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 10 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Council of Overseas Student Advisers network (OSAN) (Australia), whose members include student advisers and other interested professionals who work in tertiary, secondary and ELICOS institutions for the benefit of international students, which believes there are inconsistencies between Federal and State policies that cause confusion and dissatisfaction for significant numbers of international students studying in Australia:

(6) With overseas student health cover, why are two clauses inserted in the Medibank Private contract, the 9 month pregnancy clause and the 18 month existing condition clause, which harshly discriminate against these students during their stay in Australia.
(7) What complaints and concerns have been lodged by overseas students about their treatment by Customs officers on arrival in Australia.
(8) What training is given to port of entry Customs and Immigration officers for dealing with non-English speaking international students on arrival.

(10) What school fees are levied on the dependant children of international students in the various States and the two Territories.
(11) Are these fees payable for dependants making Australia a less attractive location in a competitive market for overseas students.
(12) What are the policies in all States for the issuing of student transport concession cards to international students and does this differ from Australian nationals.

(13) Why are a large number of international students forced to undertake placements, internships, and residencies off-shore, making the degrees conferred different from those granted to Australian residents.
(14) Will the Minister undertake to meet with OSAN representatives to discuss the details of these concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no official statistics relating to fees and charges paid by international students to the local education industry. However, it is estimated that, in 1993, international students spent approximately $1.7 billion in Australia.

(2) Statistics as at 31 March 1993 for higher education and 30 June 1993 for the `other post-secondary', schools and ELICOS sectors showed that 63,013 international students were studying in Australian institutions. This comprised: 42,666 in higher education, 6,260 in other post-secondary courses, 7,964 in secondary courses, 5,941 undertaking ELICOS courses and 182 attending primary schools.
Preliminary data for 1994 indicate that approximately 68,000 international students are currently studying in Australia.
(3) The number of students is increasing.

(4) The Government places a great deal of importance on Australia's export education industry. Australia generates considerable benefits from international goodwill and understanding when international students return home as well as obtaining substantial income [see (1) above].
(5) The Department of Employment, Education and Training has no record of the letter from Dr Ross Lehman being received. A copy of his letter has been obtained and a response is being prepared.

(6) The 9 month pregnancy clause in the Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) is a standard industry wide clause. In addition, all major private health insurers have a pre-existing medical conditions exclusion clause of 12 months. The OSHC pre-existing condition exclusion clause is for an 18 month period. The operation of the OSHC is governed by a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) dated 5 March 1993 between the then Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, the Health Insurance Commission and my Department. The MOU qualifies the operation of the pre-existing medical conditions exclusion clause by stating "This exclusion does not apply where a medical practitioner reasonably certifies, and Medibank Private agrees, that the student required emergency or unforeseen treatment in Australia in order that the student can continue his or her course of study."
(7) My Department has no knowledge of complaints made to the Australian Customs Service (ACS) or to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA).
(8) This is a matter for the ACS and DIEA.

(9) My Department has not produced general information in languages other than English for overseas students in 1993-94. It has provided funding to several peak education bodies, including the International Development Program (IDP) of the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, to develop and produce materials which describe Australian education and training systems and services in other languages. My Department is currently funding a project to assess the availability and relevance of such materials.

(10) State and Territory and Commonwealth Governments agreed in 1991 that from 1 March 1992 dependants of fee-paying international students are themselves considered to be fee-paying international students and are liable to pay a fee that reflects the full cost of their schooling.

If a student dependant enrols in a government school, a nationally agreed annual fee may be payable to the education authority of the State or Territory concerned. Currently, the fees are $3,500 per annum for primary education; $4,500 per annum for junior secondary education; and $5,500 for senior secondary education. Additional ESL (English as a Second Language) services, if needed, may incur a separate fee to cover the additional tuition costs. If the student dependant enrols in a non-government school, the school may charge the student a fee which reflects the full cost of providing the place to the student.
Some dependants of international students are exempted from the agreed national fee. They get places in Australian government schools on the same basis as Australian students. They are:
the dependants of subsidised international students who enrolled in courses before 1 January 1990; and
the dependants of international students in receipt of sponsorship or scholarships from the Australian Government, from higher education institutions or from approved non-government organisations.

Responsibility for approving non-government scholarships for the purpose of exempting dependants from school fees belongs with the States and Territories. Many States and Territories have provided further exemptions for equity, marketing and legislative reasons. In a case where an exemption is granted that student place becomes ineligible for Commonwealth funding.

Application of the 1991 agreement is not uniform across the States and Territories. This is currently being examined by a Task Force under the auspices of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA). It is expected that the Task Force will report to MCEETYA later this year and recommend ways to achieve greater national consistency in school fees charged for dependants of international students.

(11) Surveys of international students commissioned by my Department indicate that the decision to study in Australia is influenced less by perceived cost levels than by factors such as a positive recommendation by a friend or a relative; the perception that Australia offers an enjoyable lifestyle and a safe social environment; and the existence of quality assurance mechanisms, such as that embodied in the Commonwealth's Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991.

(12) The Commonwealth Government has no responsibility for transport concessions to international students. These are a matter for determination by each State/Territory Government or local authority providing the service. I am advised that all States and Territories provide travel concessions for Australian students, but New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Tasmania do not extend these concessions to international students.

The maintenance by DEET of a comprehensive and up-to-date list of all such concessions would require considerable resources. Education and training providers are better placed to stay abreast of changes in eligibility for local concessions. They are asked to provide comprehensive information, including information on access to student concessions, to all prospective international students. DEET has a number of consultative arrangements with State/Territory authorities where policies relevant to the export of education services are discussed.

(13) All medical students, whether Australian or international students, who graduate from an Australian medical school receive the same degree, usually described as MBBS. In order to gain professional registration as a medical practitioner in Australia, all graduates of Australian medical schools, whether Australian or international students, are required to undertake an internship year. The provision of internship places and their funding lie with State/Territory Health Departments.

The State/Territory Departments and the Australian medical schools have generally made it clear that no medical student, whether local or from overseas, can be guaranteed an internship place in the State/Territory hospital systems. In practice, all students wishing to undertake an internship in Australia, up to and including students graduating in 1993, have been offered an internship place.

However, from 1995 onwards, there will be a shortage of internship places available to both Australian and international students. States' and Territories' health authorities have indicated their intention to assign priority for placements to Australian nationals, permanent residents, medical graduates from New Zealand universities and overseas qualified medical graduates who, as permanent residents, are seeking professional registration in Australia and then to international students.
The Commonwealth Government is pursuing resolution of this issue through the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council (AHMAC).
(14) I am prepared to receive representations from individuals and professional bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the cost to the community of osteoporosis, related injuries and treatment such as hip replacement.
(2) Why is there no Medicare rebate for densitometry for women with a family history of osteoporosis who are known to be at high risk.
(3) Does the Government intend to grant a Medicare rebate for these tests in the future; if so, to whom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The significance of osteoporosis in Australia in terms of its incidence and costs was one of a range of issues considered by a workshop of osteoporosis experts convened by the Deputy Prime Minister and the then Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, the Hon. Brian Howe MP, in August 1992. The workshop reviewed available data sources and concluded that it was difficult to estimate accurately the extent of osteoporosis in Australia because of the lack of comprehensive national data. It was agreed that osteoporosis could affect up to one in three Australian women and a smaller proportion of men. It was also noted that two community-based studies which are being conducted would provide more direct estimates of the incidence and costs of osteoporosis in Australia: namely, the Dubbo Osteoporosis Study and the Geelong Study.
On the issue of the annual cost of osteoporosis to the Australian community, the workshop noted that this had been estimated as ranging from $200 million to $500 million.

(2) The Medicare benefits arrangements for bone densitometry, which were introduced on 1 March 1994, follow the expert advice of the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC) on their specification and implementation. MBAC is an independent statutory body, comprising eight medical practitioners from a range of disciplines, which advises the Minister for Human Services and Health on the application of Medicare benefits to specified health services.

In developing its advice, MBAC reviewed current scientific knowledge and clinical practice in regard to bone densitometry and consulted with experts in the osteoporosis and bone densitometry fields. MBAC recommended that the payment of Medicare benefits should be confined to two clinical applications of bone densitometry, with a series of measures to promote quality and appropriate use of the technology. These are, firstly, in the confirmation and monitoring of established osteoporosis and, secondly, in the diagnosis and monitoring of bone loss associated with a specific set of clinical conditions and/or treatments including, among others, rheumatoid arthritis and chronic renal disease. Two items have been included in the Medicare Benefits Schedule corresponding to these two recommended clinical applications.

On the issue of the use of bone densitometry as a screening tool to detect developing osteoporosis, MBAC concluded that there was insufficient scientific evidence to warrant the payment of Medicare benefits for this purpose. However, women who are receiving hormone replacement therapy (HRT), or other treatments for osteoporosis, are eligible for Medicare benefits for bone densitometry as part of the monitoring of their condition.

(3) In line with MBAC's recommendations, the Medicare benefit arrangements for bone densitometry will be reviewed twelve months after their introduction. The review will consider the current arrangements, new evidence on the clinical role of bone densitometry, and developments in bone densitometry technology.
